340 
341 /*************************************************************************
342 This structure is a clusterization engine.
343 
344 You should not try to access its fields directly.
345 Use ALGLIB functions in order to work with this object.
346 
347  -- ALGLIB --
348  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
349 *************************************************************************/
350 class _clusterizerstate_owner
351 {
352 public:
353  _clusterizerstate_owner();
354  _clusterizerstate_owner(const _clusterizerstate_owner &rhs);
355  _clusterizerstate_owner& operator=(const _clusterizerstate_owner &rhs);
356  virtual ~_clusterizerstate_owner();
357  alglib_impl::clusterizerstate* c_ptr();
358  alglib_impl::clusterizerstate* c_ptr() const;
359 protected:
360  alglib_impl::clusterizerstate *p_struct;
361 };
362 class clusterizerstate : public _clusterizerstate_owner
363 {
364 public:
365  clusterizerstate();
366  clusterizerstate(const clusterizerstate &rhs);
367  clusterizerstate& operator=(const clusterizerstate &rhs);
368  virtual ~clusterizerstate();
369 
370 };
371 
372 
373 /*************************************************************************
374 This structure is used to store results of the agglomerative hierarchical
375 clustering (AHC).
376 
377 Following information is returned:
378 
379 * NPoints contains number of points in the original dataset
380 
381 * Z contains information about merges performed (see below). Z contains
382  indexes from the original (unsorted) dataset and it can be used when you
383  need to know what points were merged. However, it is not convenient when
384  you want to build a dendrograd (see below).
385 
386 * if you want to build dendrogram, you can use Z, but it is not good
387  option, because Z contains indexes from unsorted dataset. Dendrogram
388  built from such dataset is likely to have intersections. So, you have to
389  reorder you points before building dendrogram.
390  Permutation which reorders point is returned in P. Another representation
391  of merges, which is more convenient for dendorgram construction, is
392  returned in PM.
393 
394 * more information on format of Z, P and PM can be found below and in the
395  examples from ALGLIB Reference Manual.
396 
397 FORMAL DESCRIPTION OF FIELDS:
398  NPoints number of points
399  Z array[NPoints-1,2], contains indexes of clusters
400  linked in pairs to form clustering tree. I-th row
401  corresponds to I-th merge:
402  * Z[I,0] - index of the first cluster to merge
403  * Z[I,1] - index of the second cluster to merge
404  * Z[I,0]<Z[I,1]
405  * clusters are numbered from 0 to 2*NPoints-2, with
406  indexes from 0 to NPoints-1 corresponding to points
407  of the original dataset, and indexes from NPoints to
408  2*NPoints-2 correspond to clusters generated by
409  subsequent merges (I-th row of Z creates cluster
410  with index NPoints+I).
411 
412  IMPORTANT: indexes in Z[] are indexes in the ORIGINAL,
413  unsorted dataset. In addition to Z algorithm outputs
414  permutation which rearranges points in such way that
415  subsequent merges are performed on adjacent points
416  (such order is needed if you want to build dendrogram).
417  However, indexes in Z are related to original,
418  unrearranged sequence of points.
419 
420  P array[NPoints], permutation which reorders points for
421  dendrogram construction. P[i] contains index of the
422  position where we should move I-th point of the
423  original dataset in order to apply merges PZ/PM.
424 
425  PZ same as Z, but for permutation of points given by P.
426  The only thing which changed are indexes of the
427  original points; indexes of clusters remained same.
428 
429  MergeDist array[NPoints-1], contains distances between clusters
430  being merged (MergeDist[i] correspond to merge stored
431  in Z[i,...]).
432 
433  PM array[NPoints-1,6], another representation of merges,
434  which is suited for dendrogram construction. It deals
435  with rearranged points (permutation P is applied) and
436  represents merges in a form which different from one
437  used by Z.
438  For each I from 0 to NPoints-2, I-th row of PM represents
439  merge performed on two clusters C0 and C1. Here:
440  * C0 contains points with indexes PM[I,0]...PM[I,1]
441  * C1 contains points with indexes PM[I,2]...PM[I,3]
442  * indexes stored in PM are given for dataset sorted
443  according to permutation P
444  * PM[I,1]=PM[I,2]-1 (only adjacent clusters are merged)
445  * PM[I,0]<=PM[I,1], PM[I,2]<=PM[I,3], i.e. both
446  clusters contain at least one point
447  * heights of "subdendrograms" corresponding to C0/C1
448  are stored in PM[I,4] and PM[I,5]. Subdendrograms
449  corresponding to single-point clusters have
450  height=0. Dendrogram of the merge result has height
451  H=max(H0,H1)+1.
452 
453 NOTE: there is one-to-one correspondence between merges described by Z and
454  PM. I-th row of Z describes same merge of clusters as I-th row of PM,
455  with "left" cluster from Z corresponding to the "left" one from PM.
456 
457  -- ALGLIB --
458  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
459 *************************************************************************/
460 class _ahcreport_owner
461 {
462 public:
463  _ahcreport_owner();
464  _ahcreport_owner(const _ahcreport_owner &rhs);
465  _ahcreport_owner& operator=(const _ahcreport_owner &rhs);
466  virtual ~_ahcreport_owner();
467  alglib_impl::ahcreport* c_ptr();
468  alglib_impl::ahcreport* c_ptr() const;
469 protected:
470  alglib_impl::ahcreport *p_struct;
471 };
472 class ahcreport : public _ahcreport_owner
473 {
474 public:
475  ahcreport();
476  ahcreport(const ahcreport &rhs);
477  ahcreport& operator=(const ahcreport &rhs);
478  virtual ~ahcreport();
479  ae_int_t &npoints;
480  integer_1d_array p;
481  integer_2d_array z;
482  integer_2d_array pz;
483  integer_2d_array pm;
484  real_1d_array mergedist;
485 
486 };
487 
488 
489 /*************************************************************************
490 This structure is used to store results of the k-means++ clustering
491 algorithm.
492 
493 Following information is always returned:
494 * NPoints contains number of points in the original dataset
495 * TerminationType contains completion code, negative on failure, positive
496  on success
497 * K contains number of clusters
498 
499 For positive TerminationType we return:
500 * NFeatures contains number of variables in the original dataset
501 * C, which contains centers found by algorithm
502 * CIdx, which maps points of the original dataset to clusters
503 
504 FORMAL DESCRIPTION OF FIELDS:
505  NPoints number of points, >=0
506  NFeatures number of variables, >=1
507  TerminationType completion code:
508  * -5 if distance type is anything different from
509  Euclidean metric
510  * -3 for degenerate dataset: a) less than K distinct
511  points, b) K=0 for non-empty dataset.
512  * +1 for successful completion
513  K number of clusters
514  C array[K,NFeatures], rows of the array store centers
515  CIdx array[NPoints], which contains cluster indexes
516 
517  -- ALGLIB --
518  Copyright 27.11.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
519 *************************************************************************/
520 class _kmeansreport_owner
521 {
522 public:
523  _kmeansreport_owner();
524  _kmeansreport_owner(const _kmeansreport_owner &rhs);
525  _kmeansreport_owner& operator=(const _kmeansreport_owner &rhs);
526  virtual ~_kmeansreport_owner();
527  alglib_impl::kmeansreport* c_ptr();
528  alglib_impl::kmeansreport* c_ptr() const;
529 protected:
530  alglib_impl::kmeansreport *p_struct;
531 };

541  ae_int_t &terminationtype;
542  ae_int_t &k;
543  real_2d_array c;
544  integer_1d_array cidx;
545 
546 };

635 
636 
637 /*************************************************************************
638 LRReport structure contains additional information about linear model:
639 * C - covariation matrix, array[0..NVars,0..NVars].
640  C[i,j] = Cov(A[i],A[j])
641 * RMSError - root mean square error on a training set
642 * AvgError - average error on a training set
643 * AvgRelError - average relative error on a training set (excluding
644  observations with zero function value).
645 * CVRMSError - leave-one-out cross-validation estimate of
646  generalization error. Calculated using fast algorithm
647  with O(NVars*NPoints) complexity.
648 * CVAvgError - cross-validation estimate of average error
649 * CVAvgRelError - cross-validation estimate of average relative error
650 
651 All other fields of the structure are intended for internal use and should
652 not be used outside ALGLIB.
653 *************************************************************************/
654 class _lrreport_owner
655 {
656 public:
657  _lrreport_owner();
658  _lrreport_owner(const _lrreport_owner &rhs);
659  _lrreport_owner& operator=(const _lrreport_owner &rhs);
660  virtual ~_lrreport_owner();
661  alglib_impl::lrreport* c_ptr();
662  alglib_impl::lrreport* c_ptr() const;
663 protected:
664  alglib_impl::lrreport *p_struct;
665 };
666 class lrreport : public _lrreport_owner
667 {
668 public:
669  lrreport();
670  lrreport(const lrreport &rhs);
671  lrreport& operator=(const lrreport &rhs);
672  virtual ~lrreport();
673  real_2d_array c;
674  double &rmserror;
675  double &avgerror;
676  double &avgrelerror;
677  double &cvrmserror;
678  double &cvavgerror;
679  double &cvavgrelerror;
680  ae_int_t &ncvdefects;
681  integer_1d_array cvdefects;
682 
683 };
684 
685 
686 
687 
688 
689 /*************************************************************************
690 Model's errors:
691  * RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
692  * AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
693  * RMSError - root-mean-square error
694  * AvgError - average error
695  * AvgRelError - average relative error
696 
697 NOTE 1: RelCLSError/AvgCE are zero on regression problems.
698 
699 NOTE 2: on classification problems RMSError/AvgError/AvgRelError contain
700  errors in prediction of posterior probabilities
701 *************************************************************************/
702 class _modelerrors_owner
703 {
704 public:
705  _modelerrors_owner();
706  _modelerrors_owner(const _modelerrors_owner &rhs);
707  _modelerrors_owner& operator=(const _modelerrors_owner &rhs);
708  virtual ~_modelerrors_owner();
709  alglib_impl::modelerrors* c_ptr();
710  alglib_impl::modelerrors* c_ptr() const;
711 protected:
712  alglib_impl::modelerrors *p_struct;
713 };
714 class modelerrors : public _modelerrors_owner
715 {
716 public:
717  modelerrors();
718  modelerrors(const modelerrors &rhs);
719  modelerrors& operator=(const modelerrors &rhs);
720  virtual ~modelerrors();
721  double &relclserror;
722  double &avgce;
723  double &rmserror;
724  double &avgerror;
725  double &avgrelerror;
726 
727 };

740  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron* c_ptr();
741  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron* c_ptr() const;
742 protected:
743  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron *p_struct;
744 };
745 class multilayerperceptron : public _multilayerperceptron_owner
746 {
747 public:
748  multilayerperceptron();
749  multilayerperceptron(const multilayerperceptron &rhs);
750  multilayerperceptron& operator=(const multilayerperceptron &rhs);
751  virtual ~multilayerperceptron();
752 
753 };
754 
755 /*************************************************************************
756 
757 *************************************************************************/
758 class _logitmodel_owner
759 {
760 public:
761  _logitmodel_owner();
762  _logitmodel_owner(const _logitmodel_owner &rhs);
763  _logitmodel_owner& operator=(const _logitmodel_owner &rhs);
764  virtual ~_logitmodel_owner();
765  alglib_impl::logitmodel* c_ptr();
766  alglib_impl::logitmodel* c_ptr() const;
767 protected:
768  alglib_impl::logitmodel *p_struct;
769 };

771 {
772 public:

774  logitmodel(const logitmodel &rhs);
775  logitmodel& operator=(const logitmodel &rhs);
776  virtual ~logitmodel();
777 
778 };

781 /*************************************************************************
782 MNLReport structure contains information about training process:
783 * NGrad - number of gradient calculations
784 * NHess - number of Hessian calculations
785 *************************************************************************/
786 class _mnlreport_owner
787 {
788 public:
789  _mnlreport_owner();
790  _mnlreport_owner(const _mnlreport_owner &rhs);
791  _mnlreport_owner& operator=(const _mnlreport_owner &rhs);
792  virtual ~_mnlreport_owner();
793  alglib_impl::mnlreport* c_ptr();
794  alglib_impl::mnlreport* c_ptr() const;
795 protected:
796  alglib_impl::mnlreport *p_struct;
797 };
798 class mnlreport : public _mnlreport_owner
799 {
800 public:
801  mnlreport();
802  mnlreport(const mnlreport &rhs);
803  mnlreport& operator=(const mnlreport &rhs);
804  virtual ~mnlreport();

807 
808 };
809 
810 /*************************************************************************
811 This structure is a MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver.
812 
813 You should use ALGLIB functions in order to work with this object.
814 
815  -- ALGLIB --
816  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
817 *************************************************************************/
818 class _mcpdstate_owner
819 {
820 public:
821  _mcpdstate_owner();
822  _mcpdstate_owner(const _mcpdstate_owner &rhs);
823  _mcpdstate_owner& operator=(const _mcpdstate_owner &rhs);
824  virtual ~_mcpdstate_owner();
825  alglib_impl::mcpdstate* c_ptr();
826  alglib_impl::mcpdstate* c_ptr() const;
827 protected:
828  alglib_impl::mcpdstate *p_struct;
829 };
830 class mcpdstate : public _mcpdstate_owner
831 {
832 public:
833  mcpdstate();
834  mcpdstate(const mcpdstate &rhs);
835  mcpdstate& operator=(const mcpdstate &rhs);
836  virtual ~mcpdstate();
837 
838 };
839 
840 
841 /*************************************************************************
842 This structure is a MCPD training report:
843  InnerIterationsCount - number of inner iterations of the
844  underlying optimization algorithm
845  OuterIterationsCount - number of outer iterations of the
846  underlying optimization algorithm
847  NFEV - number of merit function evaluations
848  TerminationType - termination type
849  (same as for MinBLEIC optimizer, positive
850  values denote success, negative ones -
851  failure)
852 
853  -- ALGLIB --
854  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
855 *************************************************************************/
856 class _mcpdreport_owner
857 {
858 public:
859  _mcpdreport_owner();
860  _mcpdreport_owner(const _mcpdreport_owner &rhs);
861  _mcpdreport_owner& operator=(const _mcpdreport_owner &rhs);
862  virtual ~_mcpdreport_owner();
863  alglib_impl::mcpdreport* c_ptr();
864  alglib_impl::mcpdreport* c_ptr() const;
865 protected:
866  alglib_impl::mcpdreport *p_struct;
867 };
868 class mcpdreport : public _mcpdreport_owner
869 {
870 public:
871  mcpdreport();
872  mcpdreport(const mcpdreport &rhs);
873  mcpdreport& operator=(const mcpdreport &rhs);
874  virtual ~mcpdreport();
875  ae_int_t &inneriterationscount;
876  ae_int_t &outeriterationscount;
877  ae_int_t &nfev;
878  ae_int_t &terminationtype;
879 
880 };
881 
882 /*************************************************************************
883 Neural networks ensemble
884 *************************************************************************/
885 class _mlpensemble_owner
886 {
887 public:
888  _mlpensemble_owner();
889  _mlpensemble_owner(const _mlpensemble_owner &rhs);
890  _mlpensemble_owner& operator=(const _mlpensemble_owner &rhs);
891  virtual ~_mlpensemble_owner();
892  alglib_impl::mlpensemble* c_ptr();

894 protected:

897 class mlpensemble : public _mlpensemble_owner

906 
907 /*************************************************************************
908 Training report:
909  * RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
910  * AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
911  * RMSError - root-mean-square error
912  * AvgError - average error
913  * AvgRelError - average relative error
914  * NGrad - number of gradient calculations
915  * NHess - number of Hessian calculations
916  * NCholesky - number of Cholesky decompositions
917 
918 NOTE 1: RelCLSError/AvgCE are zero on regression problems.
919 
920 NOTE 2: on classification problems RMSError/AvgError/AvgRelError contain
921  errors in prediction of posterior probabilities
922 *************************************************************************/
923 class _mlpreport_owner
924 {
925 public:
926  _mlpreport_owner();
927  _mlpreport_owner(const _mlpreport_owner &rhs);
928  _mlpreport_owner& operator=(const _mlpreport_owner &rhs);
929  virtual ~_mlpreport_owner();
930  alglib_impl::mlpreport* c_ptr();
931  alglib_impl::mlpreport* c_ptr() const;
932 protected:
933  alglib_impl::mlpreport *p_struct;
934 };
935 class mlpreport : public _mlpreport_owner
936 {
937 public:
938  mlpreport();
939  mlpreport(const mlpreport &rhs);
940  mlpreport& operator=(const mlpreport &rhs);
941  virtual ~mlpreport();
942  double &relclserror;
943  double &avgce;
944  double &rmserror;
945  double &avgerror;
946  double &avgrelerror;
947  ae_int_t &ngrad;
948  ae_int_t &nhess;
949  ae_int_t &ncholesky;
950 
951 };
952 
953 
954 /*************************************************************************
955 Cross-validation estimates of generalization error
956 *************************************************************************/

959 public:

962  _mlpcvreport_owner& operator=(const _mlpcvreport_owner &rhs);
963  virtual ~_mlpcvreport_owner();
964  alglib_impl::mlpcvreport* c_ptr();
965  alglib_impl::mlpcvreport* c_ptr() const;
966 protected:
967  alglib_impl::mlpcvreport *p_struct;
968 };

984 
985 /*************************************************************************
986 Trainer object for neural network.
987 
988 You should not try to access fields of this object directly - use ALGLIB
989 functions to work with this object.
990 *************************************************************************/
991 class _mlptrainer_owner
992 {
993 public:
994  _mlptrainer_owner();
995  _mlptrainer_owner(const _mlptrainer_owner &rhs);
996  _mlptrainer_owner& operator=(const _mlptrainer_owner &rhs);
997  virtual ~_mlptrainer_owner();
998  alglib_impl::mlptrainer* c_ptr();
999  alglib_impl::mlptrainer* c_ptr() const;
1000 protected:
1001  alglib_impl::mlptrainer *p_struct;
1002 };
1003 class mlptrainer : public _mlptrainer_owner
1004 {
1005 public:
1006  mlptrainer();
1007  mlptrainer(const mlptrainer &rhs);
1008  mlptrainer& operator=(const mlptrainer &rhs);
1009  virtual ~mlptrainer();
1010 
1011 };
1012 
1013 /*************************************************************************
1014 Optimal binary classification
1015 
1016 Algorithms finds optimal (=with minimal cross-entropy) binary partition.
1017 Internal subroutine.
1018 
1019 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1020  A - array[0..N-1], variable
1021  C - array[0..N-1], class numbers (0 or 1).
1022  N - array size
1023 
1024 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1025  Info - completion code:
1026  * -3, all values of A[] are same (partition is impossible)
1027  * -2, one of C[] is incorrect (<0, >1)
1028  * -1, incorrect pararemets were passed (N<=0).
1029  * 1, OK
1030  Threshold- partiton boundary. Left part contains values which are
1031  strictly less than Threshold. Right part contains values
1032  which are greater than or equal to Threshold.
1033  PAL, PBL- probabilities P(0|v<Threshold) and P(1|v<Threshold)
1034  PAR, PBR- probabilities P(0|v>=Threshold) and P(1|v>=Threshold)
1035  CVE - cross-validation estimate of cross-entropy
1036 
1037  -- ALGLIB --
1038  Copyright 22.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1039 *************************************************************************/
1040 void dsoptimalsplit2(const real_1d_array &a, const integer_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, ae_int_t &info, double &threshold, double &pal, double &pbl, double &par, double &pbr, double &cve);
1041 
1042 
1043 /*************************************************************************
1044 Optimal partition, internal subroutine. Fast version.
1045 
1046 Accepts:
1047  A array[0..N-1] array of attributes array[0..N-1]
1048  C array[0..N-1] array of class labels
1049  TiesBuf array[0..N] temporaries (ties)
1050  CntBuf array[0..2*NC-1] temporaries (counts)
1051  Alpha centering factor (0<=alpha<=1, recommended value - 0.05)
1052  BufR array[0..N-1] temporaries
1053  BufI array[0..N-1] temporaries
1054 
1055 Output:
1056  Info error code (">0"=OK, "<0"=bad)
1057  RMS training set RMS error
1058  CVRMS leave-one-out RMS error
1059 
1060 Note:
1061  content of all arrays is changed by subroutine;
1062  it doesn't allocate temporaries.
1063 
1064  -- ALGLIB --
1065  Copyright 11.12.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1066 *************************************************************************/
1067 void dsoptimalsplit2fast(real_1d_array &a, integer_1d_array &c, integer_1d_array &tiesbuf, integer_1d_array &cntbuf, real_1d_array &bufr, integer_1d_array &bufi, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nc, const double alpha, ae_int_t &info, double &threshold, double &rms, double &cvrms);
1068 
1069 /*************************************************************************
1070 This function initializes clusterizer object. Newly initialized object is
1071 empty, i.e. it does not contain dataset. You should use it as follows:
1072 1. creation
1073 2. dataset is added with ClusterizerSetPoints()
1074 3. additional parameters are set
1075 3. clusterization is performed with one of the clustering functions
1076 
1077  -- ALGLIB --
1078  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1079 *************************************************************************/
1080 void clusterizercreate(clusterizerstate &s);
1081 
1082 
1083 /*************************************************************************
1084 This function adds dataset to the clusterizer structure.
1085 
1086 This function overrides all previous calls of ClusterizerSetPoints() or
1087 ClusterizerSetDistances().
1088 
1089 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1090  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1091  XY - array[NPoints,NFeatures], dataset
1092  NPoints - number of points, >=0
1093  NFeatures- number of features, >=1
1094  DistType- distance function:
1095  * 0 Chebyshev distance (L-inf norm)
1096  * 1 city block distance (L1 norm)
1097  * 2 Euclidean distance (L2 norm)
1098  * 10 Pearson correlation:
1099  dist(a,b) = 1-corr(a,b)
1100  * 11 Absolute Pearson correlation:
1101  dist(a,b) = 1-|corr(a,b)|
1102  * 12 Uncentered Pearson correlation (cosine of the angle):
1103  dist(a,b) = a'*b/(|a|*|b|)
1104  * 13 Absolute uncentered Pearson correlation
1105  dist(a,b) = |a'*b|/(|a|*|b|)
1106  * 20 Spearman rank correlation:
1107  dist(a,b) = 1-rankcorr(a,b)
1108  * 21 Absolute Spearman rank correlation
1109  dist(a,b) = 1-|rankcorr(a,b)|
1110 
1111 NOTE 1: different distance functions have different performance penalty:
1112  * Euclidean or Pearson correlation distances are the fastest ones
1113  * Spearman correlation distance function is a bit slower
1114  * city block and Chebyshev distances are order of magnitude slower
1115 
1116  The reason behing difference in performance is that correlation-based
1117  distance functions are computed using optimized linear algebra kernels,
1118  while Chebyshev and city block distance functions are computed using
1119  simple nested loops with two branches at each iteration.
1120 
1121 NOTE 2: different clustering algorithms have different limitations:
1122  * agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithms may be used with
1123  any kind of distance metric
1124  * k-means++ clustering algorithm may be used only with Euclidean
1125  distance function
1126  Thus, list of specific clustering algorithms you may use depends
1127  on distance function you specify when you set your dataset.
1128 
1129  -- ALGLIB --
1130  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1131 *************************************************************************/
1132 void clusterizersetpoints(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nfeatures, const ae_int_t disttype);
1133 void clusterizersetpoints(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t disttype);
1134 
1135 
1136 /*************************************************************************
1137 This function adds dataset given by distance matrix to the clusterizer
1138 structure. It is important that dataset is not given explicitly - only
1139 distance matrix is given.
1140 
1141 This function overrides all previous calls of ClusterizerSetPoints() or
1142 ClusterizerSetDistances().
1143 
1144 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1145  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1146  D - array[NPoints,NPoints], distance matrix given by its upper
1147  or lower triangle (main diagonal is ignored because its
1148  entries are expected to be zero).
1149  NPoints - number of points
1150  IsUpper - whether upper or lower triangle of D is given.
1151 
1152 NOTE 1: different clustering algorithms have different limitations:
1153  * agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithms may be used with
1154  any kind of distance metric, including one which is given by
1155  distance matrix
1156  * k-means++ clustering algorithm may be used only with Euclidean
1157  distance function and explicitly given points - it can not be
1158  used with dataset given by distance matrix
1159  Thus, if you call this function, you will be unable to use k-means
1160  clustering algorithm to process your problem.
1161 
1162  -- ALGLIB --
1163  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1164 *************************************************************************/
1165 void clusterizersetdistances(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &d, const ae_int_t npoints, const bool isupper);
1166 void clusterizersetdistances(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &d, const bool isupper);
1167 
1168 
1169 /*************************************************************************
1170 This function sets agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithm
1171 
1172 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1173  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1174  Algo - algorithm type:
1175  * 0 complete linkage (default algorithm)
1176  * 1 single linkage
1177  * 2 unweighted average linkage
1178  * 3 weighted average linkage
1179 
1180  -- ALGLIB --
1181  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1182 *************************************************************************/
1183 void clusterizersetahcalgo(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t algo);
1184 
1185 
1186 /*************************************************************************
1187 This function sets k-means++ properties : number of restarts and maximum
1188 number of iterations per one run.
1189 
1190 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1191  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1192  Restarts- restarts count, >=1.
1193  k-means++ algorithm performs several restarts and chooses
1194  best set of centers (one with minimum squared distance).
1195  MaxIts - maximum number of k-means iterations performed during one
1196  run. >=0, zero value means that algorithm performs unlimited
1197  number of iterations.
1198 
1199  -- ALGLIB --
1200  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1201 *************************************************************************/
1202 void clusterizersetkmeanslimits(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t restarts, const ae_int_t maxits);
1203 
1204 
1205 /*************************************************************************
1206 This function performs agglomerative hierarchical clustering
1207 
1208 FOR USERS OF SMP EDITION:
1209 
1210  ! This function can utilize multicore capabilities of your system. In
1211  ! order to do this you have to call version with "smp_" prefix, which
1212  ! indicates that multicore code will be used.
1213  !
1214  ! This note is given for users of SMP edition; if you use GPL edition,
1215  ! or commercial edition of ALGLIB without SMP support, you still will
1216  ! be able to call smp-version of this function, but all computations
1217  ! will be done serially.
1218  !
1219  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
1220  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
1221  !
1222  ! You should remember that starting/stopping worker thread always have
1223  ! non-zero cost. Multicore version is pretty efficient on large
1224  ! problems which need more than 1.000.000 operations to be solved,
1225  ! gives moderate speed-up in mid-range (from 100.000 to 1.000.000 CPU
1226  ! cycles), but gives no speed-up for small problems (less than 100.000
1227  ! operations).
1228 
1229 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1230  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1231 
1232 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1233  Rep - clustering results; see description of AHCReport
1234  structure for more information.
1235 
1236 NOTE 1: hierarchical clustering algorithms require large amounts of memory.
1237  In particular, this implementation needs sizeof(double)*NPoints^2
1238  bytes, which are used to store distance matrix. In case we work
1239  with user-supplied matrix, this amount is multiplied by 2 (we have
1240  to store original matrix and to work with its copy).
1241 
1242  For example, problem with 10000 points would require 800M of RAM,
1243  even when working in a 1-dimensional space.
1244 
1245  -- ALGLIB --
1246  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1247 *************************************************************************/
1248 void clusterizerrunahc(const clusterizerstate &s, ahcreport &rep);
1249 void smp_clusterizerrunahc(const clusterizerstate &s, ahcreport &rep);
1250 
1251 
1252 /*************************************************************************
1253 This function performs clustering by k-means++ algorithm.
1254 
1255 You may change algorithm properties like number of restarts or iterations
1256 limit by calling ClusterizerSetKMeansLimits() functions.
1257 
1258 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1259  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
1260  K - number of clusters, K>=0.
1261  K can be zero only when algorithm is called for empty
1262  dataset, in this case completion code is set to
1263  success (+1).
1264  If K=0 and dataset size is non-zero, we can not
1265  meaningfully assign points to some center (there are no
1266  centers because K=0) and return -3 as completion code
1267  (failure).
1268 
1269 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1270  Rep - clustering results; see description of KMeansReport
1271  structure for more information.
1272 
1273 NOTE 1: k-means clustering can be performed only for datasets with
1274  Euclidean distance function. Algorithm will return negative
1275  completion code in Rep.TerminationType in case dataset was added
1276  to clusterizer with DistType other than Euclidean (or dataset was
1277  specified by distance matrix instead of explicitly given points).
1278 
1279  -- ALGLIB --
1280  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1281 *************************************************************************/
1282 void clusterizerrunkmeans(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t k, kmeansreport &rep);
1283 
1284 
1285 /*************************************************************************
1286 This function returns distance matrix for dataset
1287 
1288 FOR USERS OF SMP EDITION:
1289 
1290  ! This function can utilize multicore capabilities of your system. In
1291  ! order to do this you have to call version with "smp_" prefix, which
1292  ! indicates that multicore code will be used.
1293  !
1294  ! This note is given for users of SMP edition; if you use GPL edition,
1295  ! or commercial edition of ALGLIB without SMP support, you still will
1296  ! be able to call smp-version of this function, but all computations
1297  ! will be done serially.
1298  !
1299  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
1300  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
1301  !
1302  ! You should remember that starting/stopping worker thread always have
1303  ! non-zero cost. Multicore version is pretty efficient on large
1304  ! problems which need more than 1.000.000 operations to be solved,
1305  ! gives moderate speed-up in mid-range (from 100.000 to 1.000.000 CPU
1306  ! cycles), but gives no speed-up for small problems (less than 100.000
1307  ! operations).
1308 
1309 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1310  XY - array[NPoints,NFeatures], dataset
1311  NPoints - number of points, >=0
1312  NFeatures- number of features, >=1
1313  DistType- distance function:
1314  * 0 Chebyshev distance (L-inf norm)
1315  * 1 city block distance (L1 norm)
1316  * 2 Euclidean distance (L2 norm)
1317  * 10 Pearson correlation:
1318  dist(a,b) = 1-corr(a,b)
1319  * 11 Absolute Pearson correlation:
1320  dist(a,b) = 1-|corr(a,b)|
1321  * 12 Uncentered Pearson correlation (cosine of the angle):
1322  dist(a,b) = a'*b/(|a|*|b|)
1323  * 13 Absolute uncentered Pearson correlation
1324  dist(a,b) = |a'*b|/(|a|*|b|)
1325  * 20 Spearman rank correlation:
1326  dist(a,b) = 1-rankcorr(a,b)
1327  * 21 Absolute Spearman rank correlation
1328  dist(a,b) = 1-|rankcorr(a,b)|
1329 
1330 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1331  D - array[NPoints,NPoints], distance matrix
1332  (full matrix is returned, with lower and upper triangles)
1333 
1334 NOTES: different distance functions have different performance penalty:
1335  * Euclidean or Pearson correlation distances are the fastest ones
1336  * Spearman correlation distance function is a bit slower
1337  * city block and Chebyshev distances are order of magnitude slower
1338 
1339  The reason behing difference in performance is that correlation-based
1340  distance functions are computed using optimized linear algebra kernels,
1341  while Chebyshev and city block distance functions are computed using
1342  simple nested loops with two branches at each iteration.
1343 
1344  -- ALGLIB --
1345  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1346 *************************************************************************/
1347 void clusterizergetdistances(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nfeatures, const ae_int_t disttype, real_2d_array &d);
1348 void smp_clusterizergetdistances(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nfeatures, const ae_int_t disttype, real_2d_array &d);
1349 
1350 
1351 /*************************************************************************
1352 This function takes as input clusterization report Rep, desired clusters
1353 count K, and builds top K clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree.
1354 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
1355 
1356 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1357  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
1358  K - desired number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints.
1359  K can be zero only when NPoints=0.
1360 
1361 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1362  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
1363  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
1364  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
1365  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
1366  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
1367  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
1368  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
1369 
1370 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
1371  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
1372  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
1373  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
1374  clusters stand on its own.
1375 
1376 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
1377  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
1378  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
1379  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
1380  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
1381  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
1382  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
1383  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
1384  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
1385 
1386 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
1387  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
1388  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
1389  (up to O(N*log(K))).
1390 
1391  -- ALGLIB --
1392  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1393 *************************************************************************/
1394 void clusterizergetkclusters(const ahcreport &rep, const ae_int_t k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz);
1395 
1396 
1397 /*************************************************************************
1398 This function accepts AHC report Rep, desired minimum intercluster
1399 distance and returns top clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree
1400 which are separated by distance R or HIGHER.
1401 
1402 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
1403 
1404 There is one more function with similar name - ClusterizerSeparatedByCorr,
1405 which returns clusters with intercluster correlation equal to R or LOWER
1406 (note: higher for distance, lower for correlation).
1407 
1408 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1409  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
1410  R - desired minimum intercluster distance, R>=0
1411 
1412 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1413  K - number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints
1414  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
1415  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
1416  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
1417  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
1418  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
1419  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
1420  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
1421 
1422 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
1423  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
1424  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
1425  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
1426  clusters stand on its own.
1427 
1428 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
1429  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
1430  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
1431  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
1432  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
1433  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
1434  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
1435  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
1436  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
1437 
1438 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
1439  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
1440  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
1441  (up to O(N*log(K))).
1442 
1443  -- ALGLIB --
1444  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1445 *************************************************************************/
1446 void clusterizerseparatedbydist(const ahcreport &rep, const double r, ae_int_t &k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz);
1447 
1448 
1449 /*************************************************************************
1450 This function accepts AHC report Rep, desired maximum intercluster
1451 correlation and returns top clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree
1452 which are separated by correlation R or LOWER.
1453 
1454 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
1455 
1456 There is one more function with similar name - ClusterizerSeparatedByDist,
1457 which returns clusters with intercluster distance equal to R or HIGHER
1458 (note: higher for distance, lower for correlation).
1459 
1460 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1461  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
1462  R - desired maximum intercluster correlation, -1<=R<=+1
1463 
1464 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1465  K - number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints
1466  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
1467  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
1468  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
1469  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
1470  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
1471  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
1472  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
1473 
1474 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
1475  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
1476  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
1477  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
1478  clusters stand on its own.
1479 
1480 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
1481  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
1482  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
1483  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
1484  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
1485  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
1486  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
1487  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
1488  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
1489 
1490 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
1491  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
1492  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
1493  (up to O(N*log(K))).
1494 
1495  -- ALGLIB --
1496  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
1497 *************************************************************************/
1498 void clusterizerseparatedbycorr(const ahcreport &rep, const double r, ae_int_t &k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz);
1499 
1500 /*************************************************************************
1501 k-means++ clusterization.
1502 Backward compatibility function, we recommend to use CLUSTERING subpackage
1503 as better replacement.
1504 
1505  -- ALGLIB --
1506  Copyright 21.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1507 *************************************************************************/
1508 void kmeansgenerate(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, real_2d_array &c, integer_1d_array &xyc);
1509 
1510 /*************************************************************************
1511 This function serializes data structure to string.
1512 
1513 Important properties of s_out:
1514 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
1515 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
1516  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
1517 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
1518  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
1519  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
1520  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
1521  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
1522  nor you should change case of letters.
1523 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
1524  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
1525  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
1526  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
1527  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
1528  and vice versa.
1529 *************************************************************************/
1530 void dfserialize(decisionforest &obj, std::string &s_out);
1531 
1532 
1533 /*************************************************************************
1534 This function unserializes data structure from string.
1535 *************************************************************************/
1536 void dfunserialize(std::string &s_in, decisionforest &obj);
1537 
1538 
1539 /*************************************************************************
1540 This subroutine builds random decision forest.
1541 
1542 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1543  XY - training set
1544  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=1
1545  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
1546  NClasses - task type:
1547  * NClasses=1 - regression task with one
1548  dependent variable
1549  * NClasses>1 - classification task with
1550  NClasses classes.
1551  NTrees - number of trees in a forest, NTrees>=1.
1552  recommended values: 50-100.
1553  R - percent of a training set used to build
1554  individual trees. 0<R<=1.
1555  recommended values: 0.1 <= R <= 0.66.
1556 
1557 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1558  Info - return code:
1559  * -2, if there is a point with class number
1560  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
1561  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
1562  (NPoints<1, NVars<1, NClasses<1, NTrees<1, R<=0
1563  or R>1).
1564  * 1, if task has been solved
1565  DF - model built
1566  Rep - training report, contains error on a training set
1567  and out-of-bag estimates of generalization error.
1568 
1569  -- ALGLIB --
1570  Copyright 19.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1571 *************************************************************************/
1572 void dfbuildrandomdecisionforest(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, const ae_int_t ntrees, const double r, ae_int_t &info, decisionforest &df, dfreport &rep);
1573 
1574 
1575 /*************************************************************************
1576 This subroutine builds random decision forest.
1577 This function gives ability to tune number of variables used when choosing
1578 best split.
1579 
1580 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1581  XY - training set
1582  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=1
1583  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
1584  NClasses - task type:
1585  * NClasses=1 - regression task with one
1586  dependent variable
1587  * NClasses>1 - classification task with
1588  NClasses classes.
1589  NTrees - number of trees in a forest, NTrees>=1.
1590  recommended values: 50-100.
1591  NRndVars - number of variables used when choosing best split
1592  R - percent of a training set used to build
1593  individual trees. 0<R<=1.
1594  recommended values: 0.1 <= R <= 0.66.
1595 
1596 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1597  Info - return code:
1598  * -2, if there is a point with class number
1599  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
1600  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
1601  (NPoints<1, NVars<1, NClasses<1, NTrees<1, R<=0
1602  or R>1).
1603  * 1, if task has been solved
1604  DF - model built
1605  Rep - training report, contains error on a training set
1606  and out-of-bag estimates of generalization error.
1607 
1608  -- ALGLIB --
1609  Copyright 19.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1610 *************************************************************************/
1611 void dfbuildrandomdecisionforestx1(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, const ae_int_t ntrees, const ae_int_t nrndvars, const double r, ae_int_t &info, decisionforest &df, dfreport &rep);
1612 
1613 
1614 /*************************************************************************
1615 Procesing
1616 
1617 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1618  DF - decision forest model
1619  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
1620 
1621 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1622  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
1623  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
1624 
1625 See also DFProcessI.
1626 
1627  -- ALGLIB --
1628  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1629 *************************************************************************/
1630 void dfprocess(const decisionforest &df, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
1631 
1632 
1633 /*************************************************************************
1634 'interactive' variant of DFProcess for languages like Python which support
1635 constructs like "Y = DFProcessI(DF,X)" and interactive mode of interpreter
1636 
1637 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
1638 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
1639 when you call it from command line.
1640 
1641  -- ALGLIB --
1642  Copyright 28.02.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1643 *************************************************************************/
1644 void dfprocessi(const decisionforest &df, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
1645 
1646 
1647 /*************************************************************************
1648 Relative classification error on the test set
1649 
1650 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1651  DF - decision forest model
1652  XY - test set
1653  NPoints - test set size
1654 
1655 RESULT:
1656  percent of incorrectly classified cases.
1657  Zero if model solves regression task.
1658 
1659  -- ALGLIB --
1660  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1661 *************************************************************************/
1662 double dfrelclserror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1663 
1664 
1665 /*************************************************************************
1666 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
1667 
1668 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1669  DF - decision forest model
1670  XY - test set
1671  NPoints - test set size
1672 
1673 RESULT:
1674  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
1675  Zero if model solves regression task.
1676 
1677  -- ALGLIB --
1678  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1679 *************************************************************************/
1680 double dfavgce(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1681 
1682 
1683 /*************************************************************************
1684 RMS error on the test set
1685 
1686 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1687  DF - decision forest model
1688  XY - test set
1689  NPoints - test set size
1690 
1691 RESULT:
1692  root mean square error.
1693  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
1694  classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
1695  probabilities.
1696 
1697  -- ALGLIB --
1698  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1699 *************************************************************************/
1700 double dfrmserror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1701 
1702 
1703 /*************************************************************************
1704 Average error on the test set
1705 
1706 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1707  DF - decision forest model
1708  XY - test set
1709  NPoints - test set size
1710 
1711 RESULT:
1712  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
1713  classification task, it means average error when estimating posterior
1714  probabilities.
1715 
1716  -- ALGLIB --
1717  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1718 *************************************************************************/
1719 double dfavgerror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1720 
1721 
1722 /*************************************************************************
1723 Average relative error on the test set
1724 
1725 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1726  DF - decision forest model
1727  XY - test set
1728  NPoints - test set size
1729 
1730 RESULT:
1731  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
1732  classification task, it means average relative error when estimating
1733  posterior probability of belonging to the correct class.
1734 
1735  -- ALGLIB --
1736  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1737 *************************************************************************/
1738 double dfavgrelerror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1739 
1740 /*************************************************************************
1741 Linear regression
1742 
1743 Subroutine builds model:
1744 
1745  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1] + A(N)
1746 
1747 and model found in ALGLIB format, covariation matrix, training set errors
1748 (rms, average, average relative) and leave-one-out cross-validation
1749 estimate of the generalization error. CV estimate calculated using fast
1750 algorithm with O(NPoints*NVars) complexity.
1751 
1752 When covariation matrix is calculated standard deviations of function
1753 values are assumed to be equal to RMS error on the training set.
1754 
1755 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1756  XY - training set, array [0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]:
1757  * NVars columns - independent variables
1758  * last column - dependent variable
1759  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>NVars+1
1760  NVars - number of independent variables
1761 
1762 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1763  Info - return code:
1764  * -255, in case of unknown internal error
1765  * -4, if internal SVD subroutine haven't converged
1766  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1).
1767  * 1, if subroutine successfully finished
1768  LM - linear model in the ALGLIB format. Use subroutines of
1769  this unit to work with the model.
1770  AR - additional results
1771 
1772 
1773  -- ALGLIB --
1774  Copyright 02.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1775 *************************************************************************/
1776 void lrbuild(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar);
1777 
1778 
1779 /*************************************************************************
1780 Linear regression
1781 
1782 Variant of LRBuild which uses vector of standatd deviations (errors in
1783 function values).
1784 
1785 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1786  XY - training set, array [0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]:
1787  * NVars columns - independent variables
1788  * last column - dependent variable
1789  S - standard deviations (errors in function values)
1790  array[0..NPoints-1], S[i]>0.
1791  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>NVars+1
1792  NVars - number of independent variables
1793 
1794 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1795  Info - return code:
1796  * -255, in case of unknown internal error
1797  * -4, if internal SVD subroutine haven't converged
1798  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1).
1799  * -2, if S[I]<=0
1800  * 1, if subroutine successfully finished
1801  LM - linear model in the ALGLIB format. Use subroutines of
1802  this unit to work with the model.
1803  AR - additional results
1804 
1805 
1806  -- ALGLIB --
1807  Copyright 02.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1808 *************************************************************************/
1809 void lrbuilds(const real_2d_array &xy, const real_1d_array &s, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar);
1810 
1811 
1812 /*************************************************************************
1813 Like LRBuildS, but builds model
1814 
1815  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1]
1816 
1817 i.e. with zero constant term.
1818 
1819  -- ALGLIB --
1820  Copyright 30.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1821 *************************************************************************/
1822 void lrbuildzs(const real_2d_array &xy, const real_1d_array &s, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar);
1823 
1824 
1825 /*************************************************************************
1826 Like LRBuild but builds model
1827 
1828  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1]
1829 
1830 i.e. with zero constant term.
1831 
1832  -- ALGLIB --
1833  Copyright 30.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1834 *************************************************************************/
1835 void lrbuildz(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar);
1836 
1837 
1838 /*************************************************************************
1839 Unpacks coefficients of linear model.
1840 
1841 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1842  LM - linear model in ALGLIB format
1843 
1844 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1845  V - coefficients, array[0..NVars]
1846  constant term (intercept) is stored in the V[NVars].
1847  NVars - number of independent variables (one less than number
1848  of coefficients)
1849 
1850  -- ALGLIB --
1851  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1852 *************************************************************************/
1853 void lrunpack(const linearmodel &lm, real_1d_array &v, ae_int_t &nvars);
1854 
1855 
1856 /*************************************************************************
1857 "Packs" coefficients and creates linear model in ALGLIB format (LRUnpack
1858 reversed).
1859 
1860 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1861  V - coefficients, array[0..NVars]
1862  NVars - number of independent variables
1863 
1864 OUTPUT PAREMETERS:
1865  LM - linear model.
1866 
1867  -- ALGLIB --
1868  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1869 *************************************************************************/
1870 void lrpack(const real_1d_array &v, const ae_int_t nvars, linearmodel &lm);
1871 
1872 
1873 /*************************************************************************
1874 Procesing
1875 
1876 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1877  LM - linear model
1878  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
1879 
1880 Result:
1881  value of linear model regression estimate
1882 
1883  -- ALGLIB --
1884  Copyright 03.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1885 *************************************************************************/
1886 double lrprocess(const linearmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x);
1887 
1888 
1889 /*************************************************************************
1890 RMS error on the test set
1891 
1892 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1893  LM - linear model
1894  XY - test set
1895  NPoints - test set size
1896 
1897 RESULT:
1898  root mean square error.
1899 
1900  -- ALGLIB --
1901  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1902 *************************************************************************/
1903 double lrrmserror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1904 
1905 
1906 /*************************************************************************
1907 Average error on the test set
1908 
1909 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1910  LM - linear model
1911  XY - test set
1912  NPoints - test set size
1913 
1914 RESULT:
1915  average error.
1916 
1917  -- ALGLIB --
1918  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1919 *************************************************************************/
1920 double lravgerror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1921 
1922 
1923 /*************************************************************************
1924 RMS error on the test set
1925 
1926 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1927  LM - linear model
1928  XY - test set
1929  NPoints - test set size
1930 
1931 RESULT:
1932  average relative error.
1933 
1934  -- ALGLIB --
1935  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
1936 *************************************************************************/
1937 double lravgrelerror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
1938 
1939 /*************************************************************************
1940 Filters: simple moving averages (unsymmetric).
1941 
1942 This filter replaces array by results of SMA(K) filter. SMA(K) is defined
1943 as filter which averages at most K previous points (previous - not points
1944 AROUND central point) - or less, in case of the first K-1 points.
1945 
1946 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1947  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
1948  in this case only first N points are processed.
1949  N - points count, N>=0
1950  K - K>=1 (K can be larger than N , such cases will be
1951  correctly handled). Window width. K=1 corresponds to
1952  identity transformation (nothing changes).
1953 
1954 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1955  X - array, whose first N elements were processed with SMA(K)
1956 
1957 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
1958  allocate temporary arrays.
1959 
1960 NOTE 2: this algorithm makes only one pass through array and uses running
1961  sum to speed-up calculation of the averages. Additional measures
1962  are taken to ensure that running sum on a long sequence of zero
1963  elements will be correctly reset to zero even in the presence of
1964  round-off error.
1965 
1966 NOTE 3: this is unsymmetric version of the algorithm, which does NOT
1967  averages points after the current one. Only X[i], X[i-1], ... are
1968  used when calculating new value of X[i]. We should also note that
1969  this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
1970  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
1971 
1972  -- ALGLIB --
1973  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
1974 *************************************************************************/
1975 void filtersma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t k);
1976 void filtersma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t k);
1977 
1978 
1979 /*************************************************************************
1980 Filters: exponential moving averages.
1981 
1982 This filter replaces array by results of EMA(alpha) filter. EMA(alpha) is
1983 defined as filter which replaces X[] by S[]:
1984  S[0] = X[0]
1985  S[t] = alpha*X[t] + (1-alpha)*S[t-1]
1986 
1987 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1988  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
1989  in this case only first N points are processed.
1990  N - points count, N>=0
1991  alpha - 0<alpha<=1, smoothing parameter.
1992 
1993 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1994  X - array, whose first N elements were processed
1995  with EMA(alpha)
1996 
1997 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
1998  allocate temporary arrays.
1999 
2000 NOTE 2: this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
2001  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
2002 
2003 NOTE 3: technical analytis users quite often work with EMA coefficient
2004  expressed in DAYS instead of fractions. If you want to calculate
2005  EMA(N), where N is a number of days, you can use alpha=2/(N+1).
2006 
2007  -- ALGLIB --
2008  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2009 *************************************************************************/
2010 void filterema(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const double alpha);
2011 void filterema(real_1d_array &x, const double alpha);
2012 
2013 
2014 /*************************************************************************
2015 Filters: linear regression moving averages.
2016 
2017 This filter replaces array by results of LRMA(K) filter.
2018 
2019 LRMA(K) is defined as filter which, for each data point, builds linear
2020 regression model using K prevous points (point itself is included in
2021 these K points) and calculates value of this linear model at the point in
2022 question.
2023 
2024 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2025  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
2026  in this case only first N points are processed.
2027  N - points count, N>=0
2028  K - K>=1 (K can be larger than N , such cases will be
2029  correctly handled). Window width. K=1 corresponds to
2030  identity transformation (nothing changes).
2031 
2032 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2033  X - array, whose first N elements were processed with SMA(K)
2034 
2035 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
2036  allocate temporary arrays.
2037 
2038 NOTE 2: this algorithm makes only one pass through array and uses running
2039  sum to speed-up calculation of the averages. Additional measures
2040  are taken to ensure that running sum on a long sequence of zero
2041  elements will be correctly reset to zero even in the presence of
2042  round-off error.
2043 
2044 NOTE 3: this is unsymmetric version of the algorithm, which does NOT
2045  averages points after the current one. Only X[i], X[i-1], ... are
2046  used when calculating new value of X[i]. We should also note that
2047  this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
2048  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
2049 
2050  -- ALGLIB --
2051  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2052 *************************************************************************/
2053 void filterlrma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t k);
2054 void filterlrma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t k);
2055 
2056 /*************************************************************************
2057 Multiclass Fisher LDA
2058 
2059 Subroutine finds coefficients of linear combination which optimally separates
2060 training set on classes.
2061 
2062 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2063  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars].
2064  First NVars columns store values of independent
2065  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
2066  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
2067  values are rounded to nearest integer.
2068  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=0
2069  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
2070  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
2071 
2072 
2073 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2074  Info - return code:
2075  * -4, if internal EVD subroutine hasn't converged
2076  * -2, if there is a point with class number
2077  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
2078  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<0,
2079  NVars<1, NClasses<2)
2080  * 1, if task has been solved
2081  * 2, if there was a multicollinearity in training set,
2082  but task has been solved.
2083  W - linear combination coefficients, array[0..NVars-1]
2084 
2085  -- ALGLIB --
2086  Copyright 31.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2087 *************************************************************************/
2088 void fisherlda(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &w);
2089 
2090 
2091 /*************************************************************************
2092 N-dimensional multiclass Fisher LDA
2093 
2094 Subroutine finds coefficients of linear combinations which optimally separates
2095 training set on classes. It returns N-dimensional basis whose vector are sorted
2096 by quality of training set separation (in descending order).
2097 
2098 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2099  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars].
2100  First NVars columns store values of independent
2101  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
2102  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
2103  values are rounded to nearest integer.
2104  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=0
2105  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
2106  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
2107 
2108 
2109 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2110  Info - return code:
2111  * -4, if internal EVD subroutine hasn't converged
2112  * -2, if there is a point with class number
2113  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
2114  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<0,
2115  NVars<1, NClasses<2)
2116  * 1, if task has been solved
2117  * 2, if there was a multicollinearity in training set,
2118  but task has been solved.
2119  W - basis, array[0..NVars-1,0..NVars-1]
2120  columns of matrix stores basis vectors, sorted by
2121  quality of training set separation (in descending order)
2122 
2123  -- ALGLIB --
2124  Copyright 31.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2125 *************************************************************************/
2126 void fisherldan(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, real_2d_array &w);
2127 
2128 /*************************************************************************
2129 This function serializes data structure to string.
2130 
2131 Important properties of s_out:
2132 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
2133 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
2134  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
2135 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
2136  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
2137  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
2138  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
2139  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
2140  nor you should change case of letters.
2141 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
2142  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
2143  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
2144  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
2145  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
2146  and vice versa.
2147 *************************************************************************/
2148 void mlpserialize(multilayerperceptron &obj, std::string &s_out);
2149 
2150 
2151 /*************************************************************************
2152 This function unserializes data structure from string.
2153 *************************************************************************/
2154 void mlpunserialize(std::string &s_in, multilayerperceptron &obj);
2155 
2156 
2157 /*************************************************************************
2158 Creates neural network with NIn inputs, NOut outputs, without hidden
2159 layers, with linear output layer. Network weights are filled with small
2160 random values.
2161 
2162  -- ALGLIB --
2163  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2164 *************************************************************************/
2165 void mlpcreate0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network);
2166 
2167 
2168 /*************************************************************************
2169 Same as MLPCreate0, but with one hidden layer (NHid neurons) with
2170 non-linear activation function. Output layer is linear.
2171 
2172  -- ALGLIB --
2173  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2174 *************************************************************************/
2175 void mlpcreate1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network);
2176 
2177 
2178 /*************************************************************************
2179 Same as MLPCreate0, but with two hidden layers (NHid1 and NHid2 neurons)
2180 with non-linear activation function. Output layer is linear.
2181  $ALL
2182 
2183  -- ALGLIB --
2184  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2185 *************************************************************************/
2186 void mlpcreate2(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid1, const ae_int_t nhid2, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network);
2187 
2188 
2189 /*************************************************************************
2190 Creates neural network with NIn inputs, NOut outputs, without hidden
2191 layers with non-linear output layer. Network weights are filled with small
2192 random values.
2193 
2194 Activation function of the output layer takes values:
2195 
2196  (B, +INF), if D>=0
2197 
2198 or
2199 
2200  (-INF, B), if D<0.
2201 
2202 
2203  -- ALGLIB --
2204  Copyright 30.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2205 *************************************************************************/
2206 void mlpcreateb0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, multilayerperceptron &network);
2207

2214 *************************************************************************/
2215 void mlpcreateb1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, multilayerperceptron &network);

2222  Copyright 30.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey

2255 
2256 /*************************************************************************
2257 Creates classifier network with NIn inputs and NOut possible classes.
2258 Network contains no hidden layers and linear output layer with SOFTMAX-
2259 normalization (so outputs sums up to 1.0 and converge to posterior
2260 probabilities).
2261 
2262  -- ALGLIB --
2263  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2264 *************************************************************************/
2265 void mlpcreatec0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network);
