2342 Tells whether network is SOFTMAX-normalized (i.e. classifier) or not.
2343 
2344  -- ALGLIB --
2345  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2346 *************************************************************************/
2347 bool mlpissoftmax(const multilayerperceptron &network);
2348 
2349 
2350 /*************************************************************************
2351 This function returns total number of layers (including input, hidden and
2352 output layers).
2353 
2354  -- ALGLIB --
2355  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2356 *************************************************************************/
2357 ae_int_t mlpgetlayerscount(const multilayerperceptron &network);
2358 
2359 
2360 /*************************************************************************
2361 This function returns size of K-th layer.
2362 
2363 K=0 corresponds to input layer, K=CNT-1 corresponds to output layer.
2364 
2365 Size of the output layer is always equal to the number of outputs, although
2366 when we have softmax-normalized network, last neuron doesn't have any
2367 connections - it is just zero.
2368 
2369  -- ALGLIB --
2370  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2371 *************************************************************************/
2372 ae_int_t mlpgetlayersize(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k);
2373 
2374 
2375 /*************************************************************************
2376 This function returns offset/scaling coefficients for I-th input of the
2377 network.
2378 
2379 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2380  Network - network
2381  I - input index
2382 
2383 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2384  Mean - mean term
2385  Sigma - sigma term, guaranteed to be nonzero.
2386 
2387 I-th input is passed through linear transformation
2388  IN[i] = (IN[i]-Mean)/Sigma
2389 before feeding to the network
2390 
2391  -- ALGLIB --
2392  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2393 *************************************************************************/
2394 void mlpgetinputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, double &mean, double &sigma);
2395 
2396 
2397 /*************************************************************************
2398 This function returns offset/scaling coefficients for I-th output of the
2399 network.
2400 
2401 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2402  Network - network
2403  I - input index
2404 
2405 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2406  Mean - mean term
2407  Sigma - sigma term, guaranteed to be nonzero.
2408 
2409 I-th output is passed through linear transformation
2410  OUT[i] = OUT[i]*Sigma+Mean
2411 before returning it to user. In case we have SOFTMAX-normalized network,
2412 we return (Mean,Sigma)=(0.0,1.0).
2413 
2414  -- ALGLIB --
2415  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2416 *************************************************************************/
2417 void mlpgetoutputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, double &mean, double &sigma);
2418 
2419 
2420 /*************************************************************************
2421 This function returns information about Ith neuron of Kth layer
2422 
2423 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2424  Network - network
2425  K - layer index
2426  I - neuron index (within layer)
2427 
2428 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2429  FKind - activation function type (used by MLPActivationFunction())
2430  this value is zero for input or linear neurons
2431  Threshold - also called offset, bias
2432  zero for input neurons
2433 
2434 NOTE: this function throws exception if layer or neuron with given index
2435 do not exists.
2436 
2437  -- ALGLIB --
2438  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2439 *************************************************************************/
2440 void mlpgetneuroninfo(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t i, ae_int_t &fkind, double &threshold);
2441 
2442 
2443 /*************************************************************************
2444 This function returns information about connection from I0-th neuron of
2445 K0-th layer to I1-th neuron of K1-th layer.
2446 
2447 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2448  Network - network
2449  K0 - layer index
2450  I0 - neuron index (within layer)
2451  K1 - layer index
2452  I1 - neuron index (within layer)
2453 
2454 RESULT:
2455  connection weight (zero for non-existent connections)
2456 
2457 This function:
2458 1. throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do not exists.
2459 2. returns zero if neurons exist, but there is no connection between them
2460 
2461  -- ALGLIB --
2462  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2463 *************************************************************************/
2464 double mlpgetweight(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k0, const ae_int_t i0, const ae_int_t k1, const ae_int_t i1);
2465 
2466 
2467 /*************************************************************************
2468 This function sets offset/scaling coefficients for I-th input of the
2469 network.
2470 
2471 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2472  Network - network
2473  I - input index
2474  Mean - mean term
2475  Sigma - sigma term (if zero, will be replaced by 1.0)
2476 
2477 NTE: I-th input is passed through linear transformation
2478  IN[i] = (IN[i]-Mean)/Sigma
2479 before feeding to the network. This function sets Mean and Sigma.
2480 
2481  -- ALGLIB --
2482  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2483 *************************************************************************/
2484 void mlpsetinputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, const double mean, const double sigma);
2485 
2486 
2487 /*************************************************************************
2488 This function sets offset/scaling coefficients for I-th output of the
2489 network.
2490 
2491 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2492  Network - network
2493  I - input index
2494  Mean - mean term
2495  Sigma - sigma term (if zero, will be replaced by 1.0)
2496 
2497 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2498 
2499 NOTE: I-th output is passed through linear transformation
2500  OUT[i] = OUT[i]*Sigma+Mean
2501 before returning it to user. This function sets Sigma/Mean. In case we
2502 have SOFTMAX-normalized network, you can not set (Sigma,Mean) to anything
2503 other than(0.0,1.0) - this function will throw exception.
2504 
2505  -- ALGLIB --
2506  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2507 *************************************************************************/
2508 void mlpsetoutputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, const double mean, const double sigma);
2509 
2510 
2511 /*************************************************************************
2512 This function modifies information about Ith neuron of Kth layer
2513 
2514 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2515  Network - network
2516  K - layer index
2517  I - neuron index (within layer)
2518  FKind - activation function type (used by MLPActivationFunction())
2519  this value must be zero for input neurons
2520  (you can not set activation function for input neurons)
2521  Threshold - also called offset, bias
2522  this value must be zero for input neurons
2523  (you can not set threshold for input neurons)
2524 
2525 NOTES:
2526 1. this function throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do
2527  not exists.
2528 2. this function also throws exception when you try to set non-linear
2529  activation function for input neurons (any kind of network) or for output
2530  neurons of classifier network.
2531 3. this function throws exception when you try to set non-zero threshold for
2532  input neurons (any kind of network).
2533 
2534  -- ALGLIB --
2535  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2536 *************************************************************************/
2537 void mlpsetneuroninfo(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t fkind, const double threshold);
2538 
2539 
2540 /*************************************************************************
2541 This function modifies information about connection from I0-th neuron of
2542 K0-th layer to I1-th neuron of K1-th layer.
2543 
2544 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2545  Network - network
2546  K0 - layer index
2547  I0 - neuron index (within layer)
2548  K1 - layer index
2549  I1 - neuron index (within layer)
2550  W - connection weight (must be zero for non-existent
2551  connections)
2552 
2553 This function:
2554 1. throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do not exists.
2555 2. throws exception if you try to set non-zero weight for non-existent
2556  connection
2557 
2558  -- ALGLIB --
2559  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
2560 *************************************************************************/
2561 void mlpsetweight(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k0, const ae_int_t i0, const ae_int_t k1, const ae_int_t i1, const double w);
2562 
2563 
2564 /*************************************************************************
2565 Neural network activation function
2566 
2567 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2568  NET - neuron input
2569  K - function index (zero for linear function)
2570 
2571 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2572  F - function
2573  DF - its derivative
2574  D2F - its second derivative
2575 
2576  -- ALGLIB --
2577  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2578 *************************************************************************/
2579 void mlpactivationfunction(const double net, const ae_int_t k, double &f, double &df, double &d2f);
2580 
2581 
2582 /*************************************************************************
2583 Procesing
2584 
2585 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2586  Network - neural network
2587  X - input vector, array[0..NIn-1].
2588 
2589 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2590  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
2591  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
2592 
2593 See also MLPProcessI
2594 
2595  -- ALGLIB --
2596  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2597 *************************************************************************/
2598 void mlpprocess(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
2599 
2600 
2601 /*************************************************************************
2602 'interactive' variant of MLPProcess for languages like Python which
2603 support constructs like "Y = MLPProcess(NN,X)" and interactive mode of the
2604 interpreter
2605 
2606 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
2607 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
2608 when you call it from command line.
2609 
2610  -- ALGLIB --
2611  Copyright 21.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2612 *************************************************************************/
2613 void mlpprocessi(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
2614 
2615 
2616 /*************************************************************************
2617 Error of the neural network on dataset.
2618 
2619 
2620 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2621 
2622  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2623  ! this function:
2624  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2625  ! * SSE support
2626  !
2627  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2628  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x, depending on your CPU)
2629  !
2630  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2631  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2632  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2633  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2634  !
2635  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2636  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2637  ! * use C++ computational core
2638  !
2639  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2640  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2641  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2642  !
2643  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2644  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2645 
2646 
2647 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2648  Network - neural network;
2649  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2650  training set format;
2651  NPoints - points count.
2652 
2653 RESULT:
2654  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
2655 
2656 DATASET FORMAT:
2657 
2658 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
2659 networks, another one for classification networks.
2660 
2661 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
2662 format is used:
2663 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
2664 * each row corresponds to one example
2665 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
2666 
2667 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
2668 dataset format is used:
2669 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
2670 * each row corresponds to one example
2671 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
2672  NClasses-1).
2673 
2674  -- ALGLIB --
2675  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2676 *************************************************************************/
2677 double mlperror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2678 double smp_mlperror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2679 
2680 
2681 /*************************************************************************
2682 Error of the neural network on dataset given by sparse matrix.
2683 
2684 
2685 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2686 
2687  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2688  ! this function:
2689  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2690  ! * SSE support
2691  !
2692  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2693  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x, depending on your CPU)
2694  !
2695  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2696  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2697  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2698  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2699  !
2700  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2701  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2702  ! * use C++ computational core
2703  !
2704  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2705  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2706  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2707  !
2708  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2709  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2710 
2711 
2712 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2713  Network - neural network
2714  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2715  training set format. This function checks correctness
2716  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
2717  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
2718  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
2719  storage.
2720  NPoints - points count, >=0
2721 
2722 RESULT:
2723  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
2724 
2725 DATASET FORMAT:
2726 
2727 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
2728 networks, another one for classification networks.
2729 
2730 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
2731 format is used:
2732 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
2733 * each row corresponds to one example
2734 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
2735 
2736 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
2737 dataset format is used:
2738 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
2739 * each row corresponds to one example
2740 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
2741  NClasses-1).
2742 
2743  -- ALGLIB --
2744  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
2745 *************************************************************************/
2746 double mlperrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2747 double smp_mlperrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2748 
2749 
2750 /*************************************************************************
2751 Natural error function for neural network, internal subroutine.
2752 
2753 NOTE: this function is single-threaded. Unlike other error function, it
2754 receives no speed-up from being executed in SMP mode.
2755 
2756  -- ALGLIB --
2757  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2758 *************************************************************************/
2759 double mlperrorn(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize);
2760 
2761 
2762 /*************************************************************************
2763 Classification error of the neural network on dataset.
2764 
2765 
2766 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2767 
2768  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2769  ! this function:
2770  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2771  ! * SSE support
2772  !
2773  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2774  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
2775  !
2776  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2777  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2778  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2779  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2780  !
2781  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2782  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2783  ! * use C++ computational core
2784  !
2785  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2786  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2787  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2788  !
2789  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2790  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2791 
2792 
2793 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2794  Network - neural network;
2795  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2796  training set format;
2797  NPoints - points count.
2798 
2799 RESULT:
2800  classification error (number of misclassified cases)
2801 
2802 DATASET FORMAT:
2803 
2804 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
2805 networks, another one for classification networks.
2806 
2807 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
2808 format is used:
2809 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
2810 * each row corresponds to one example
2811 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
2812 
2813 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
2814 dataset format is used:
2815 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
2816 * each row corresponds to one example
2817 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
2818  NClasses-1).
2819 
2820  -- ALGLIB --
2821  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2822 *************************************************************************/
2823 ae_int_t mlpclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2824 ae_int_t smp_mlpclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2825 
2826 
2827 /*************************************************************************
2828 Relative classification error on the test set.
2829 
2830 
2831 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2832 
2833  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2834  ! this function:
2835  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2836  ! * SSE support
2837  !
2838  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2839  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
2840  !
2841  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2842  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2843  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2844  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2845  !
2846  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2847  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2848  ! * use C++ computational core
2849  !
2850  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2851  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2852  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2853  !
2854  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2855  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2856 
2857 
2858 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2859  Network - neural network;
2860  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2861  training set format;
2862  NPoints - points count.
2863 
2864 RESULT:
2865 Percent of incorrectly classified cases. Works both for classifier
2866 networks and general purpose networks used as classifiers.
2867 
2868 DATASET FORMAT:
2869 
2870 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
2871 networks, another one for classification networks.
2872 
2873 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
2874 format is used:
2875 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
2876 * each row corresponds to one example
2877 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
2878 
2879 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
2880 dataset format is used:
2881 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
2882 * each row corresponds to one example
2883 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
2884  NClasses-1).
2885 
2886  -- ALGLIB --
2887  Copyright 25.12.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2888 *************************************************************************/
2889 double mlprelclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2890 double smp_mlprelclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2891 
2892 
2893 /*************************************************************************
2894 Relative classification error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
2895 
2896 
2897 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2898 
2899  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2900  ! this function:
2901  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2902  ! * SSE support
2903  !
2904  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2905  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
2906  !
2907  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2908  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2909  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2910  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2911  !
2912  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2913  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2914  ! * use C++ computational core
2915  !
2916  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2917  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2918  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2919  !
2920  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2921  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2922 
2923 
2924 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2925  Network - neural network;
2926  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2927  training set format. Sparse matrix must use CRS format
2928  for storage.
2929  NPoints - points count, >=0.
2930 
2931 RESULT:
2932 Percent of incorrectly classified cases. Works both for classifier
2933 networks and general purpose networks used as classifiers.
2934 
2935 DATASET FORMAT:
2936 
2937 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
2938 networks, another one for classification networks.
2939 
2940 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
2941 format is used:
2942 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
2943 * each row corresponds to one example
2944 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
2945 
2946 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
2947 dataset format is used:
2948 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
2949 * each row corresponds to one example
2950 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
2951  NClasses-1).
2952 
2953  -- ALGLIB --
2954  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
2955 *************************************************************************/
2956 double mlprelclserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2957 double smp_mlprelclserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
2958 
2959 
2960 /*************************************************************************
2961 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set.
2962 
2963 
2964 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
2965 
2966  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
2967  ! this function:
2968  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
2969  ! * SSE support
2970  !
2971  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
2972  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
2973  !
2974  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
2975  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
2976  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
2977  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
2978  !
2979  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
2980  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
2981  ! * use C++ computational core
2982  !
2983  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
2984  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
2985  ! but all computations will be done serially.
2986  !
2987  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
2988  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
2989 
2990 
2991 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2992  Network - neural network;
2993  XY - training set, see below for information on the
2994  training set format;
2995  NPoints - points count.
2996 
2997 RESULT:
2998 CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
2999 Zero if network solves regression task.
3000 
3001 DATASET FORMAT:
3002 
3003 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3004 networks, another one for classification networks.
3005 
3006 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3007 format is used:
3008 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3009 * each row corresponds to one example
3010 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3011 
3012 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3013 dataset format is used:
3014 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3015 * each row corresponds to one example
3016 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3017  NClasses-1).
3018 
3019  -- ALGLIB --
3020  Copyright 08.01.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3021 *************************************************************************/
3022 double mlpavgce(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3023 double smp_mlpavgce(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3024 
3025 
3026 /*************************************************************************
3027 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set given by
3028 sparse matrix.
3029 
3030 
3031 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3032 
3033  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3034  ! this function:
3035  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3036  ! * SSE support
3037  !
3038  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3039  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3040  !
3041  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3042  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3043  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3044  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3045  !
3046  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3047  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3048  ! * use C++ computational core
3049  !
3050  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3051  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3052  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3053  !
3054  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3055  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3056 
3057 
3058 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3059  Network - neural network;
3060  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3061  training set format. This function checks correctness
3062  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3063  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3064  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3065  storage.
3066  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3067 
3068 RESULT:
3069 CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
3070 Zero if network solves regression task.
3071 
3072 DATASET FORMAT:
3073 
3074 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3075 networks, another one for classification networks.
3076 
3077 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3078 format is used:
3079 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3080 * each row corresponds to one example
3081 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3082 
3083 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3084 dataset format is used:
3085 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3086 * each row corresponds to one example
3087 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3088  NClasses-1).
3089 
3090  -- ALGLIB --
3091  Copyright 9.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3092 *************************************************************************/
3093 double mlpavgcesparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3094 double smp_mlpavgcesparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3095 
3096 
3097 /*************************************************************************
3098 RMS error on the test set given.
3099 
3100 
3101 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3102 
3103  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3104  ! this function:
3105  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3106  ! * SSE support
3107  !
3108  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3109  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3110  !
3111  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3112  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3113  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3114  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3115  !
3116  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3117  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3118  ! * use C++ computational core
3119  !
3120  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3121  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3122  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3123  !
3124  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3125  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3126 
3127 
3128 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3129  Network - neural network;
3130  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3131  training set format;
3132  NPoints - points count.
3133 
3134 RESULT:
3135 Root mean square error. Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
3136 classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
3137 probabilities.
3138 
3139 DATASET FORMAT:
3140 
3141 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3142 networks, another one for classification networks.
3143 
3144 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3145 format is used:
3146 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3147 * each row corresponds to one example
3148 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3149 
3150 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3151 dataset format is used:
3152 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3153 * each row corresponds to one example
3154 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3155  NClasses-1).
3156 
3157  -- ALGLIB --
3158  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3159 *************************************************************************/
3160 double mlprmserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3161 double smp_mlprmserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3162 
3163 
3164 /*************************************************************************
3165 RMS error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3166 
3167 
3168 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3169 
3170  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3171  ! this function:
3172  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3173  ! * SSE support
3174  !
3175  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3176  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3177  !
3178  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3179  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3180  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3181  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3182  !
3183  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3184  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3185  ! * use C++ computational core
3186  !
3187  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3188  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3189  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3190  !
3191  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3192  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3193 
3194 
3195 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3196  Network - neural network;
3197  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3198  training set format. This function checks correctness
3199  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3200  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3201  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3202  storage.
3203  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3204 
3205 RESULT:
3206 Root mean square error. Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
3207 classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
3208 probabilities.
3209 
3210 DATASET FORMAT:
3211 
3212 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3213 networks, another one for classification networks.
3214 
3215 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3216 format is used:
3217 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3218 * each row corresponds to one example
3219 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3220 
3221 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3222 dataset format is used:
3223 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3224 * each row corresponds to one example
3225 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3226  NClasses-1).
3227 
3228  -- ALGLIB --
3229  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3230 *************************************************************************/
3231 double mlprmserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3232 double smp_mlprmserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3233 
3234 
3235 /*************************************************************************
3236 Average absolute error on the test set.
3237 
3238 
3239 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3240 
3241  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3242  ! this function:
3243  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3244  ! * SSE support
3245  !
3246  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3247  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3248  !
3249  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3250  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3251  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3252  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3253  !
3254  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3255  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3256  ! * use C++ computational core
3257  !
3258  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3259  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3260  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3261  !
3262  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3263  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3264 
3265 
3266 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3267  Network - neural network;
3268  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3269  training set format;
3270  NPoints - points count.
3271 
3272 RESULT:
3273 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3274 means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
3275 
3276 DATASET FORMAT:
3277 
3278 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3279 networks, another one for classification networks.
3280 
3281 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3282 format is used:
3283 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3284 * each row corresponds to one example
3285 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3286 
3287 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3288 dataset format is used:
3289 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3290 * each row corresponds to one example
3291 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3292  NClasses-1).
3293 
3294  -- ALGLIB --
3295  Copyright 11.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3296 *************************************************************************/
3297 double mlpavgerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3298 double smp_mlpavgerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3299 
3300 
3301 /*************************************************************************
3302 Average absolute error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3303 
3304 
3305 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3306 
3307  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3308  ! this function:
3309  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3310  ! * SSE support
3311  !
3312  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3313  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3314  !
3315  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3316  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3317  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3318  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3319  !
3320  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3321  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3322  ! * use C++ computational core
3323  !
3324  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3325  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3326  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3327  !
3328  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3329  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3330 
3331 
3332 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3333  Network - neural network;
3334  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3335  training set format. This function checks correctness
3336  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3337  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3338  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3339  storage.
3340  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3341 
3342 RESULT:
3343 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3344 means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
3345 
3346 DATASET FORMAT:
3347 
3348 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3349 networks, another one for classification networks.
3350 
3351 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3352 format is used:
3353 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3354 * each row corresponds to one example
3355 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3356 
3357 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3358 dataset format is used:
3359 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3360 * each row corresponds to one example
3361 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3362  NClasses-1).
3363 
3364  -- ALGLIB --
3365  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3366 *************************************************************************/
3367 double mlpavgerrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3368 double smp_mlpavgerrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3369 
3370 
3371 /*************************************************************************
3372 Average relative error on the test set.
3373 
3374 
3375 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3376 
3377  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3378  ! this function:
3379  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3380  ! * SSE support
3381  !
3382  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3383  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3384  !
3385  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3386  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3387  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3388  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3389  !
3390  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3391  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3392  ! * use C++ computational core
3393  !
3394  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3395  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3396  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3397  !
3398  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3399  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3400 
3401 
3402 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3403  Network - neural network;
3404  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3405  training set format;
3406  NPoints - points count.
3407 
3408 RESULT:
3409 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3410 means average relative error when estimating posterior probability of
3411 belonging to the correct class.
3412 
3413 DATASET FORMAT:
3414 
3415 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3416 networks, another one for classification networks.
3417 
3418 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3419 format is used:
3420 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3421 * each row corresponds to one example
3422 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3423 
3424 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3425 dataset format is used:
3426 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3427 * each row corresponds to one example
3428 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3429  NClasses-1).
3430 
3431  -- ALGLIB --
3432  Copyright 11.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3433 *************************************************************************/
3434 double mlpavgrelerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
3435 double smp_mlpavgrelerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);

3437

3443

3445  ! this function:
3446  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3447  ! * SSE support
3448  !
3449  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3450  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3451  !

3453  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB

3455  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3456  !

3458  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3459  ! * use C++ computational core
3460  !
3461  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3462  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3463  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3464  !
3465  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3466  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3467 
3468 
3469 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3470  Network - neural network;
3471  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3472  training set format. This function checks correctness
3473  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3474  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3475  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3476  storage.

3480 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3481 means average relative error when estimating posterior probability of
3482 belonging to the correct class.
3483 
3484 DATASET FORMAT:

3487 networks, another one for classification networks.
3488 
3489 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3490 format is used:
3491 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3492 * each row corresponds to one example
3493 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3494

3496 dataset format is used:
3497 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3498 * each row corresponds to one example
3499 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3500  NClasses-1).
3501 
3502  -- ALGLIB --
3503  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3504 *************************************************************************/
3505 double mlpavgrelerrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);

3507 
3508 
3509 /*************************************************************************
3510 Gradient calculation
3511 
3512 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3513  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3514  X - input vector, length of array must be at least NIn
3515  DesiredY- desired outputs, length of array must be at least NOut
3516  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3517  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3518  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3519  overhead.
3520 
3521 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3522  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3523  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3524 
3525  -- ALGLIB --
3526  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3527 *************************************************************************/
3528 void mlpgrad(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &desiredy, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3529 
3530 
3531 /*************************************************************************
3532 Gradient calculation (natural error function is used)
3533 
3534 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3535  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3536  X - input vector, length of array must be at least NIn
3537  DesiredY- desired outputs, length of array must be at least NOut
3538  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3539  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3540  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3541  overhead.
3542 
3543 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3544  E - error function, sum-of-squares for regression networks,
3545  cross-entropy for classification networks.
3546  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3547 
3548  -- ALGLIB --
3549  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3550 *************************************************************************/
3551 void mlpgradn(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &desiredy, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3552 
3553 
3554 /*************************************************************************
3555 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs
3556 
3557 
3558 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3559 
3560  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3561  ! this function:
3562  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3563  ! * SSE support
3564  !
3565  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3566  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3567  !
3568  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3569  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3570  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3571  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3572  !
3573  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3574  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3575  ! * use C++ computational core
3576  !
3577  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3578  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3579  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3580  !
3581  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3582  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3583 
3584 
3585 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3586  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3587  XY - original dataset in dense format; one sample = one row:
3588  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
3589  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
3590  desired outputs.
3591  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
3592  stores class number.
3593  SSize - number of elements in XY
3594  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3595  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3596  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3597  overhead.
3598 
3599 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3600  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3601  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3602 
3603  -- ALGLIB --
3604  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3605 *************************************************************************/
3606 void mlpgradbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3607 void smp_mlpgradbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3608 
3609 
3610 /*************************************************************************
3611 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs given by sparse
3612 matrices
3613 
3614 
3615 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3616 
3617  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3618  ! this function:
3619  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3620  ! * SSE support
3621  !
3622  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3623  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3624  !
3625  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3626  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3627  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3628  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3629  !
3630  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3631  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3632  ! * use C++ computational core
3633  !
3634  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3635  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3636  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3637  !
3638  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3639  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3640 
3641 
3642 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3643  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3644  XY - original dataset in sparse format; one sample = one row:
3645  * MATRIX MUST BE STORED IN CRS FORMAT
3646  * first NIn columns contain inputs.
3647  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
3648  desired outputs.
3649  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
3650  stores class number.
3651  SSize - number of elements in XY
3652  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3653  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3654  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3655  overhead.
3656 
3657 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3658  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3659  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3660 
3661  -- ALGLIB --
3662  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3663 *************************************************************************/
3664 void mlpgradbatchsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3665 void smp_mlpgradbatchsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3666 
3667 
3668 /*************************************************************************
3669 Batch gradient calculation for a subset of dataset
3670 
3671 
3672 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3673 
3674  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3675  ! this function:
3676  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3677  ! * SSE support
3678  !
3679  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3680  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3681  !
3682  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3683  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3684  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3685  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3686  !
3687  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3688  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3689  ! * use C++ computational core
3690  !
3691  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3692  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3693  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3694  !
3695  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3696  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3697 
3698 
3699 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3700  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3701  XY - original dataset in dense format; one sample = one row:
3702  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
3703  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
3704  desired outputs.
3705  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
3706  stores class number.
3707  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
3708  Idx - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize]:
3709  * Idx[I] stores row index in the original dataset which is
3710  given by XY. Gradient is calculated with respect to rows
3711  whose indexes are stored in Idx[].
3712  * Idx[] must store correct indexes; this function throws
3713  an exception in case incorrect index (less than 0 or
3714  larger than rows(XY)) is given
3715  * Idx[] may store indexes in any order and even with
3716  repetitions.
3717  SubsetSize- number of elements in Idx[] array:
3718  * positive value means that subset given by Idx[] is processed
3719  * zero value results in zero gradient
3720  * negative value means that full dataset is processed
3721  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3722  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3723  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3724  overhead.
3725 
3726 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3727  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3728  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network,
3729  array[WCount]
3730 
3731  -- ALGLIB --
3732  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3733 *************************************************************************/
3734 void mlpgradbatchsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3735 void smp_mlpgradbatchsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3736 
3737 
3738 /*************************************************************************
3739 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs for a subset of
3740 dataset given by set of indexes.
3741 
3742 
3743 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3744 
3745  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3746  ! this function:
3747  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3748  ! * SSE support
3749  !
3750  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3751  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3752  !
3753  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3754  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3755  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3756  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3757  !
3758  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3759  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3760  ! * use C++ computational core
3761  !
3762  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3763  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3764  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3765  !
3766  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3767  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3768 
3769 
3770 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3771  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3772  XY - original dataset in sparse format; one sample = one row:
3773  * MATRIX MUST BE STORED IN CRS FORMAT
3774  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
3775  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
3776  desired outputs.
3777  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
3778  stores class number.
3779  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
3780  Idx - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize]:
3781  * Idx[I] stores row index in the original dataset which is
3782  given by XY. Gradient is calculated with respect to rows
3783  whose indexes are stored in Idx[].
3784  * Idx[] must store correct indexes; this function throws
3785  an exception in case incorrect index (less than 0 or
3786  larger than rows(XY)) is given
3787  * Idx[] may store indexes in any order and even with
3788  repetitions.
3789  SubsetSize- number of elements in Idx[] array:
3790  * positive value means that subset given by Idx[] is processed
3791  * zero value results in zero gradient
3792  * negative value means that full dataset is processed
3793  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3794  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3795  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3796  overhead.
3797 
3798 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3799  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3800  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network,
3801  array[WCount]
3802 
3803 NOTE: when SubsetSize<0 is used full dataset by call MLPGradBatchSparse
3804  function.
3805 
3806  -- ALGLIB --
3807  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3808 *************************************************************************/
3809 void mlpgradbatchsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3810 void smp_mlpgradbatchsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3811 
3812 
3813 /*************************************************************************
3814 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs
3815 (natural error function is used)
3816 
3817 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3818  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3819  XY - set of inputs/outputs; one sample = one row;
3820  first NIn columns contain inputs,
3821  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
3822  SSize - number of elements in XY
3823  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3824  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3825  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3826  overhead.
3827 
3828 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3829  E - error function, sum-of-squares for regression networks,
3830  cross-entropy for classification networks.
3831  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3832 
3833  -- ALGLIB --
3834  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3835 *************************************************************************/
3836 void mlpgradnbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad);
3837 
3838 
3839 /*************************************************************************
3840 Batch Hessian calculation (natural error function) using R-algorithm.
3841 Internal subroutine.
3842 
3843  -- ALGLIB --
3844  Copyright 26.01.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey.
3845 
3846  Hessian calculation based on R-algorithm described in
3847  "Fast Exact Multiplication by the Hessian",
3848  B. A. Pearlmutter,
3849  Neural Computation, 1994.
3850 *************************************************************************/
3851 void mlphessiannbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &h);
3852 
3853 
3854 /*************************************************************************
3855 Batch Hessian calculation using R-algorithm.
3856 Internal subroutine.
3857 
3858  -- ALGLIB --
3859  Copyright 26.01.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey.
3860 
3861  Hessian calculation based on R-algorithm described in
3862  "Fast Exact Multiplication by the Hessian",
3863  B. A. Pearlmutter,
3864  Neural Computation, 1994.
3865 *************************************************************************/
3866 void mlphessianbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &h);
3867 
3868 
3869 /*************************************************************************
3870 Calculation of all types of errors.
3871 
3872 
3873 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3874 
3875  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3876  ! this function:
3877  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3878  ! * SSE support
3879  !
3880  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3881  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3882  !
3883  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3884  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3885  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3886  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3887  !
3888  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3889  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3890  ! * use C++ computational core
3891  !
3892  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3893  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3894  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3895  !
3896  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3897  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
3898 
3899 
3900 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3901  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3902  XY - original dataset; one sample = one row;
3903  first NIn columns contain inputs,
3904  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
3905  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
3906  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
3907  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array.
3908 
3909 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3910  Rep - it contains all type of errors.
3911 
3912 NOTE: when SubsetSize<0 is used full dataset by call MLPGradBatch function.
3913 
3914  -- ALGLIB --
3915  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3916 *************************************************************************/
3917 void mlpallerrorssubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, modelerrors &rep);

3930  ! * SSE support
3931  !
3932  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3933  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3934  !

3936  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3937  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3938  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3939  !
3940  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3941  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3942  ! * use C++ computational core
3943  !
3944  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3945  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3946  ! but all computations will be done serially.
3947  !
3948  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
3949  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.

3954  XY - original dataset given by sparse matrix;
3955  one sample = one row;
3956  first NIn columns contain inputs,
3957  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
3958  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;

3960  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array.

3971 void smp_mlpallerrorssparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, modelerrors &rep);

3973 
3974 /*************************************************************************
3975 Error of the neural network on dataset.
3976 
3977 
3978 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
3979 
3980  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
3981  ! this function:
3982  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
3983  ! * SSE support
3984  !
3985  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
3986  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
3987  !
3988  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
3989  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
3990  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
3991  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
3992  !
3993  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
3994  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
3995  ! * use C++ computational core
3996  !
3997  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
3998  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
3999  ! but all computations will be done serially.
4000  !
4001  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
4002  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
4003 
4004 
4005 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4006  Network - neural network;
4007  XY - training set, see below for information on the
4008  training set format;
4009  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4010  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4011  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array.
4012 
4013 RESULT:
4014  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
4015 
4016 DATASET FORMAT:
4017 
4018 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
4019 networks, another one for classification networks.
4020 
4021 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
4022 format is used:
4023 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
4024 * each row corresponds to one example
4025 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
4026 
4027 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
4028 dataset format is used:
4029 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
4030 * each row corresponds to one example
4031 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
4032  NClasses-1).
4033 
4034  -- ALGLIB --
4035  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4036 *************************************************************************/
4037 double mlperrorsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize);
4038 double smp_mlperrorsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize);
4039 
4040 
4041 /*************************************************************************
4042 Error of the neural network on sparse dataset.
4043 
4044 
4045 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
4046 
4047  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
4048  ! this function:
4049  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
4050  ! * SSE support
4051  !
4052  ! First improvement gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems.
4053  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3x depending on your CPU)
4054  !
4055  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
4056  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
4057  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
4058  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
4059  !
4060  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
4061  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
4062  ! * use C++ computational core
4063  !
4064  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
4065  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
4066  ! but all computations will be done serially.
4067  !
4068  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
4069  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
4070 
4071 
4072 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4073  Network - neural network;
4074  XY - training set, see below for information on the
4075  training set format. This function checks correctness
4076  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
4077  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
4078  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
4079  storage.
4080  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4081  it is used when SubsetSize<0;
4082  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4083  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array.
4084 
4085 RESULT:
4086  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
4087 
4088 DATASET FORMAT:
4089 
4090 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
4091 networks, another one for classification networks.
4092 
4093 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
4094 format is used:
4095 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
4096 * each row corresponds to one example
4097 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
4098 
4099 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
4100 dataset format is used:
4101 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
4102 * each row corresponds to one example
4103 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
4104  NClasses-1).
4105 
4106  -- ALGLIB --
4107  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4108 *************************************************************************/
4109 double mlperrorsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize);
4110 double smp_mlperrorsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize);
4111 
4112 /*************************************************************************
4113 This subroutine trains logit model.
4114 
4115 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4116  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]
4117  First NVars columns store values of independent
4118  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
4119  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
4120  values are rounded to nearest integer.
4121  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=1
4122  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
4123  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
4124 
4125 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4126  Info - return code:
4127  * -2, if there is a point with class number
4128  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
4129  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
4130  (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1, NClasses<2).
4131  * 1, if task has been solved
4132  LM - model built
4133  Rep - training report
4134 
4135  -- ALGLIB --
4136  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4137 *************************************************************************/
4138 void mnltrainh(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, logitmodel &lm, mnlreport &rep);
4139 
4140 
4141 /*************************************************************************
4142 Procesing
4143 
4144 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4145  LM - logit model, passed by non-constant reference
4146  (some fields of structure are used as temporaries
4147  when calculating model output).
4148  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
4149  Y - (possibly) preallocated buffer; if size of Y is less than
4150  NClasses, it will be reallocated.If it is large enough, it
4151  is NOT reallocated, so we can save some time on reallocation.
4152 
4153 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4154  Y - result, array[0..NClasses-1]
4155  Vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
4156 
4157  -- ALGLIB --
4158  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4159 *************************************************************************/
4160 void mnlprocess(const logitmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
4161 
4162 
4163 /*************************************************************************
4164 'interactive' variant of MNLProcess for languages like Python which
4165 support constructs like "Y = MNLProcess(LM,X)" and interactive mode of the
4166 interpreter
4167 
4168 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
4169 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
4170 when you call it from command line.
4171 
4172  -- ALGLIB --
4173  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4174 *************************************************************************/
4175 void mnlprocessi(const logitmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
4176 
4177 
4178 /*************************************************************************
4179 Unpacks coefficients of logit model. Logit model have form:
4180 
4181  P(class=i) = S(i) / (S(0) + S(1) + ... +S(M-1))
4182  S(i) = Exp(A[i,0]*X[0] + ... + A[i,N-1]*X[N-1] + A[i,N]), when i<M-1
4183  S(M-1) = 1
4184 
4185 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4186  LM - logit model in ALGLIB format
4187 
4188 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4189  V - coefficients, array[0..NClasses-2,0..NVars]
4190  NVars - number of independent variables
4191  NClasses - number of classes
4192 
4193  -- ALGLIB --
4194  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4195 *************************************************************************/
4196 void mnlunpack(const logitmodel &lm, real_2d_array &a, ae_int_t &nvars, ae_int_t &nclasses);
4197 
4198 
4199 /*************************************************************************
4200 "Packs" coefficients and creates logit model in ALGLIB format (MNLUnpack
4201 reversed).
4202 
4203 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4204  A - model (see MNLUnpack)
4205  NVars - number of independent variables
4206  NClasses - number of classes
4207 
4208 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4209  LM - logit model.
4210 
4211  -- ALGLIB --
4212  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4213 *************************************************************************/
4214 void mnlpack(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, logitmodel &lm);
4215 
4216 
4217 /*************************************************************************
4218 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
4219 
4220 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4221  LM - logit model
4222  XY - test set
4223  NPoints - test set size
4224 
4225 RESULT:
4226  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*ln(2)).
4227 
4228  -- ALGLIB --
4229  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4230 *************************************************************************/
4231 double mnlavgce(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
4232 
4233

4243  percent of incorrectly classified cases.

4248 double mnlrelclserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);

4260  root mean square error (error when estimating posterior probabilities).
4261

4264 *************************************************************************/
4265 double mnlrmserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);

4267 
4268 /*************************************************************************

4272  LM - logit model
4273  XY - test set
