4284 
4285 /*************************************************************************
4286 Average relative error on the test set
4287 
4288 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4289  LM - logit model
4290  XY - test set
4291  NPoints - test set size
4292 
4293 RESULT:
4294  average relative error (error when estimating posterior probabilities).
4295 
4296  -- ALGLIB --
4297  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4298 *************************************************************************/
4299 double mnlavgrelerror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize);
4300 
4301 
4302 /*************************************************************************
4303 Classification error on test set = MNLRelClsError*NPoints
4304 
4305  -- ALGLIB --
4306  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4307 *************************************************************************/
4308 ae_int_t mnlclserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
4309 
4310 /*************************************************************************
4311 DESCRIPTION:
4312 
4313 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver.
4314 
4315 This solver can be used to find transition matrix P for N-dimensional
4316 prediction problem where transition from X[i] to X[i+1] is modelled as
4317  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
4318 where X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional population vectors (components of
4319 each X are non-negative), and P is a N*N transition matrix (elements of P
4320 are non-negative, each column sums to 1.0).
4321 
4322 Such models arise when when:
4323 * there is some population of individuals
4324 * individuals can have different states
4325 * individuals can transit from one state to another
4326 * population size is constant, i.e. there is no new individuals and no one
4327  leaves population
4328 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
4329 
4330 USAGE:
4331 
4332 Here we give very brief outline of the MCPD. We strongly recommend you to
4333 read examples in the ALGLIB Reference Manual and to read ALGLIB User Guide
4334 on data analysis which is available at http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/
4335 
4336 1. User initializes algorithm state with MCPDCreate() call
4337 
4338 2. User adds one or more tracks - sequences of states which describe
4339  evolution of a system being modelled from different starting conditions
4340 
4341 3. User may add optional boundary, equality and/or linear constraints on
4342  the coefficients of P by calling one of the following functions:
4343  * MCPDSetEC() to set equality constraints
4344  * MCPDSetBC() to set bound constraints
4345  * MCPDSetLC() to set linear constraints
4346 
4347 4. Optionally, user may set custom weights for prediction errors (by
4348  default, algorithm assigns non-equal, automatically chosen weights for
4349  errors in the prediction of different components of X). It can be done
4350  with a call of MCPDSetPredictionWeights() function.
4351 
4352 5. User calls MCPDSolve() function which takes algorithm state and
4353  pointer (delegate, etc.) to callback function which calculates F/G.
4354 
4355 6. User calls MCPDResults() to get solution
4356 
4357 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4358  N - problem dimension, N>=1
4359 
4360 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4361  State - structure stores algorithm state
4362 
4363  -- ALGLIB --
4364  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4365 *************************************************************************/
4366 void mcpdcreate(const ae_int_t n, mcpdstate &s);
4367 
4368 
4369 /*************************************************************************
4370 DESCRIPTION:
4371 
4372 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
4373 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
4374 about MCPD solver.
4375 
4376 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
4377 for "Entry-state" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to X[i+1]
4378 is modelled as
4379  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
4380 where
4381  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
4382  P is a N*N transition matrix
4383 and one selected component of X[] is called "entry" state and is treated
4384 in a special way:
4385  system state always transits from "entry" state to some another state
4386  system state can not transit from any state into "entry" state
4387 Such conditions basically mean that row of P which corresponds to "entry"
4388 state is zero.
4389 
4390 Such models arise when:
4391 * there is some population of individuals
4392 * individuals can have different states
4393 * individuals can transit from one state to another
4394 * population size is NOT constant - at every moment of time there is some
4395  (unpredictable) amount of "new" individuals, which can transit into one
4396  of the states at the next turn, but still no one leaves population
4397 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
4398 * but you do NOT want to predict amount of "new" individuals because it
4399  does not depends on individuals already present (hence system can not
4400  transit INTO entry state - it can only transit FROM it).
4401 
4402 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
4403 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
4404 
4405 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4406  N - problem dimension, N>=2
4407  EntryState- index of entry state, in 0..N-1
4408 
4409 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4410  State - structure stores algorithm state
4411 
4412  -- ALGLIB --
4413  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4414 *************************************************************************/
4415 void mcpdcreateentry(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t entrystate, mcpdstate &s);
4416 
4417 
4418 /*************************************************************************
4419 DESCRIPTION:
4420 
4421 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
4422 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
4423 about MCPD solver.
4424 
4425 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
4426 for "Exit-state" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to X[i+1]
4427 is modelled as
4428  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
4429 where
4430  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
4431  P is a N*N transition matrix
4432 and one selected component of X[] is called "exit" state and is treated
4433 in a special way:
4434  system state can transit from any state into "exit" state
4435  system state can not transit from "exit" state into any other state
4436  transition operator discards "exit" state (makes it zero at each turn)
4437 Such conditions basically mean that column of P which corresponds to
4438 "exit" state is zero. Multiplication by such P may decrease sum of vector
4439 components.
4440 
4441 Such models arise when:
4442 * there is some population of individuals
4443 * individuals can have different states
4444 * individuals can transit from one state to another
4445 * population size is NOT constant - individuals can move into "exit" state
4446  and leave population at the next turn, but there are no new individuals
4447 * amount of individuals which leave population can be predicted
4448 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
4449  (including transitions into the "exit" state)
4450 
4451 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
4452 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
4453 
4454 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4455  N - problem dimension, N>=2
4456  ExitState- index of exit state, in 0..N-1
4457 
4458 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4459  State - structure stores algorithm state
4460 
4461  -- ALGLIB --
4462  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4463 *************************************************************************/
4464 void mcpdcreateexit(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t exitstate, mcpdstate &s);
4465 
4466 
4467 /*************************************************************************
4468 DESCRIPTION:
4469 
4470 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
4471 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
4472 about MCPD solver.
4473 
4474 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
4475 for "Entry-Exit-states" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to
4476 X[i+1] is modelled as
4477  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
4478 where
4479  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
4480  P is a N*N transition matrix
4481 one selected component of X[] is called "entry" state and is treated in a
4482 special way:
4483  system state always transits from "entry" state to some another state
4484  system state can not transit from any state into "entry" state
4485 and another one component of X[] is called "exit" state and is treated in
4486 a special way too:
4487  system state can transit from any state into "exit" state
4488  system state can not transit from "exit" state into any other state
4489  transition operator discards "exit" state (makes it zero at each turn)
4490 Such conditions basically mean that:
4491  row of P which corresponds to "entry" state is zero
4492  column of P which corresponds to "exit" state is zero
4493 Multiplication by such P may decrease sum of vector components.
4494 
4495 Such models arise when:
4496 * there is some population of individuals
4497 * individuals can have different states
4498 * individuals can transit from one state to another
4499 * population size is NOT constant
4500 * at every moment of time there is some (unpredictable) amount of "new"
4501  individuals, which can transit into one of the states at the next turn
4502 * some individuals can move (predictably) into "exit" state and leave
4503  population at the next turn
4504 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another,
4505  including transitions from the "entry" state and into the "exit" state.
4506 * but you do NOT want to predict amount of "new" individuals because it
4507  does not depends on individuals already present (hence system can not
4508  transit INTO entry state - it can only transit FROM it).
4509 
4510 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
4511 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
4512 
4513 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4514  N - problem dimension, N>=2
4515  EntryState- index of entry state, in 0..N-1
4516  ExitState- index of exit state, in 0..N-1
4517 
4518 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4519  State - structure stores algorithm state
4520 
4521  -- ALGLIB --
4522  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4523 *************************************************************************/
4524 void mcpdcreateentryexit(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t entrystate, const ae_int_t exitstate, mcpdstate &s);
4525 
4526 
4527 /*************************************************************************
4528 This function is used to add a track - sequence of system states at the
4529 different moments of its evolution.
4530 
4531 You may add one or several tracks to the MCPD solver. In case you have
4532 several tracks, they won't overwrite each other. For example, if you pass
4533 two tracks, A1-A2-A3 (system at t=A+1, t=A+2 and t=A+3) and B1-B2-B3, then
4534 solver will try to model transitions from t=A+1 to t=A+2, t=A+2 to t=A+3,
4535 t=B+1 to t=B+2, t=B+2 to t=B+3. But it WON'T mix these two tracks - i.e. it
4536 won't try to model transition from t=A+3 to t=B+1.
4537 
4538 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4539  S - solver
4540  XY - track, array[K,N]:
4541  * I-th row is a state at t=I
4542  * elements of XY must be non-negative (exception will be
4543  thrown on negative elements)
4544  K - number of points in a track
4545  * if given, only leading K rows of XY are used
4546  * if not given, automatically determined from size of XY
4547 
4548 NOTES:
4549 
4550 1. Track may contain either proportional or population data:
4551  * with proportional data all rows of XY must sum to 1.0, i.e. we have
4552  proportions instead of absolute population values
4553  * with population data rows of XY contain population counts and generally
4554  do not sum to 1.0 (although they still must be non-negative)
4555 
4556  -- ALGLIB --
4557  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4558 *************************************************************************/
4559 void mcpdaddtrack(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t k);
4560 void mcpdaddtrack(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy);
4561 
4562 
4563 /*************************************************************************
4564 This function is used to add equality constraints on the elements of the
4565 transition matrix P.
4566 
4567 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
4568 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
4569 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
4570 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
4571 * basic constraints (always present):
4572  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
4573  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
4574 
4575 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
4576 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
4577 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
4578  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
4579  P[0,0]=0.5
4580 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
4581 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
4582 
4583 This function can be used to place equality constraints on arbitrary
4584 subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is specified by EC, which may
4585 contain either NAN's or finite numbers from [0,1]. NAN denotes absence of
4586 constraint, finite number denotes equality constraint on specific element
4587 of P.
4588 
4589 You can also use MCPDAddEC() function which allows to ADD equality
4590 constraint for one element of P without changing constraints for other
4591 elements.
4592 
4593 These functions (MCPDSetEC and MCPDAddEC) interact as follows:
4594 * there is internal matrix of equality constraints which is stored in the
4595  MCPD solver
4596 * MCPDSetEC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
4597 * MCPDAddEC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
4598  unchanged (ADD)
4599 * thus MCPDAddEC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
4600  calls, while MCPDSetEC() completely discards all changes done to the
4601  equality constraints.
4602 
4603 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4604  S - solver
4605  EC - equality constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of EC can be
4606  either NAN's or finite numbers from [0,1]. NAN denotes
4607  absence of constraints, while finite value denotes
4608  equality constraint on the corresponding element of P.
4609 
4610 NOTES:
4611 
4612 1. infinite values of EC will lead to exception being thrown. Values less
4613 than 0.0 or greater than 1.0 will lead to error code being returned after
4614 call to MCPDSolve().
4615 
4616  -- ALGLIB --
4617  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4618 *************************************************************************/
4619 void mcpdsetec(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &ec);
4620 
4621 
4622 /*************************************************************************
4623 This function is used to add equality constraints on the elements of the
4624 transition matrix P.
4625 
4626 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
4627 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
4628 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
4629 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
4630 * basic constraints (always present):
4631  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
4632  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
4633 
4634 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
4635 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
4636 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
4637  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
4638  P[0,0]=0.5
4639 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
4640 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
4641 
4642 This function can be used to ADD equality constraint for one element of P
4643 without changing constraints for other elements.
4644 
4645 You can also use MCPDSetEC() function which allows you to specify
4646 arbitrary set of equality constraints in one call.
4647 
4648 These functions (MCPDSetEC and MCPDAddEC) interact as follows:
4649 * there is internal matrix of equality constraints which is stored in the
4650  MCPD solver
4651 * MCPDSetEC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
4652 * MCPDAddEC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
4653  unchanged (ADD)
4654 * thus MCPDAddEC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
4655  calls, while MCPDSetEC() completely discards all changes done to the
4656  equality constraints.
4657 
4658 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4659  S - solver
4660  I - row index of element being constrained
4661  J - column index of element being constrained
4662  C - value (constraint for P[I,J]). Can be either NAN (no
4663  constraint) or finite value from [0,1].
4664 
4665 NOTES:
4666 
4667 1. infinite values of C will lead to exception being thrown. Values less
4668 than 0.0 or greater than 1.0 will lead to error code being returned after
4669 call to MCPDSolve().
4670 
4671  -- ALGLIB --
4672  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4673 *************************************************************************/
4674 void mcpdaddec(const mcpdstate &s, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t j, const double c);
4675 
4676 
4677 /*************************************************************************
4678 This function is used to add bound constraints on the elements of the
4679 transition matrix P.
4680 
4681 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
4682 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
4683 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
4684 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
4685 * basic constraints (always present):
4686  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
4687  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
4688 
4689 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
4690 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
4691 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
4692  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
4693  P[0,0]=0.5
4694 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
4695 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
4696 
4697 This function can be used to place bound constraints on arbitrary
4698 subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is specified by BndL/BndU
4699 matrices, which may contain arbitrary combination of finite numbers or
4700 infinities (like -INF<x<=0.5 or 0.1<=x<+INF).
4701 
4702 You can also use MCPDAddBC() function which allows to ADD bound constraint
4703 for one element of P without changing constraints for other elements.
4704 
4705 These functions (MCPDSetBC and MCPDAddBC) interact as follows:
4706 * there is internal matrix of bound constraints which is stored in the
4707  MCPD solver
4708 * MCPDSetBC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
4709 * MCPDAddBC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
4710  unchanged (ADD)
4711 * thus MCPDAddBC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
4712  calls, while MCPDSetBC() completely discards all changes done to the
4713  equality constraints.
4714 
4715 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4716  S - solver
4717  BndL - lower bounds constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of BndL can
4718  be finite numbers or -INF.
4719  BndU - upper bounds constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of BndU can
4720  be finite numbers or +INF.
4721 
4722  -- ALGLIB --
4723  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4724 *************************************************************************/
4725 void mcpdsetbc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &bndl, const real_2d_array &bndu);
4726 
4727 
4728 /*************************************************************************
4729 This function is used to add bound constraints on the elements of the
4730 transition matrix P.
4731 
4732 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
4733 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
4734 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
4735 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
4736 * basic constraints (always present):
4737  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
4738  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
4739 
4740 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
4741 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
4742 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
4743  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
4744  P[0,0]=0.5
4745 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
4746 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
4747 
4748 This function can be used to ADD bound constraint for one element of P
4749 without changing constraints for other elements.
4750 
4751 You can also use MCPDSetBC() function which allows to place bound
4752 constraints on arbitrary subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is
4753 specified by BndL/BndU matrices, which may contain arbitrary combination
4754 of finite numbers or infinities (like -INF<x<=0.5 or 0.1<=x<+INF).
4755 
4756 These functions (MCPDSetBC and MCPDAddBC) interact as follows:
4757 * there is internal matrix of bound constraints which is stored in the
4758  MCPD solver
4759 * MCPDSetBC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
4760 * MCPDAddBC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
4761  unchanged (ADD)
4762 * thus MCPDAddBC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
4763  calls, while MCPDSetBC() completely discards all changes done to the
4764  equality constraints.
4765 
4766 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4767  S - solver
4768  I - row index of element being constrained
4769  J - column index of element being constrained
4770  BndL - lower bound
4771  BndU - upper bound
4772 
4773  -- ALGLIB --
4774  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4775 *************************************************************************/
4776 void mcpdaddbc(const mcpdstate &s, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t j, const double bndl, const double bndu);
4777 
4778 
4779 /*************************************************************************
4780 This function is used to set linear equality/inequality constraints on the
4781 elements of the transition matrix P.
4782 
4783 This function can be used to set one or several general linear constraints
4784 on the elements of P. Two types of constraints are supported:
4785 * equality constraints
4786 * inequality constraints (both less-or-equal and greater-or-equal)
4787 
4788 Coefficients of constraints are specified by matrix C (one of the
4789 parameters). One row of C corresponds to one constraint. Because
4790 transition matrix P has N*N elements, we need N*N columns to store all
4791 coefficients (they are stored row by row), and one more column to store
4792 right part - hence C has N*N+1 columns. Constraint kind is stored in the
4793 CT array.
4794 
4795 Thus, I-th linear constraint is
4796  P[0,0]*C[I,0] + P[0,1]*C[I,1] + .. + P[0,N-1]*C[I,N-1] +
4797  + P[1,0]*C[I,N] + P[1,1]*C[I,N+1] + ... +
4798  + P[N-1,N-1]*C[I,N*N-1] ?=? C[I,N*N]
4799 where ?=? can be either "=" (CT[i]=0), "<=" (CT[i]<0) or ">=" (CT[i]>0).
4800 
4801 Your constraint may involve only some subset of P (less than N*N elements).
4802 For example it can be something like
4803  P[0,0] + P[0,1] = 0.5
4804 In this case you still should pass matrix with N*N+1 columns, but all its
4805 elements (except for C[0,0], C[0,1] and C[0,N*N-1]) will be zero.
4806 
4807 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4808  S - solver
4809  C - array[K,N*N+1] - coefficients of constraints
4810  (see above for complete description)
4811  CT - array[K] - constraint types
4812  (see above for complete description)
4813  K - number of equality/inequality constraints, K>=0:
4814  * if given, only leading K elements of C/CT are used
4815  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of C/CT
4816 
4817  -- ALGLIB --
4818  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4819 *************************************************************************/
4820 void mcpdsetlc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct, const ae_int_t k);
4821 void mcpdsetlc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct);
4822 
4823 
4824 /*************************************************************************
4825 This function allows to tune amount of Tikhonov regularization being
4826 applied to your problem.
4827 
4828 By default, regularizing term is equal to r*||P-prior_P||^2, where r is a
4829 small non-zero value, P is transition matrix, prior_P is identity matrix,
4830 ||X||^2 is a sum of squared elements of X.
4831 
4832 This function allows you to change coefficient r. You can also change
4833 prior values with MCPDSetPrior() function.
4834 
4835 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4836  S - solver
4837  V - regularization coefficient, finite non-negative value. It
4838  is not recommended to specify zero value unless you are
4839  pretty sure that you want it.
4840 
4841  -- ALGLIB --
4842  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4843 *************************************************************************/
4844 void mcpdsettikhonovregularizer(const mcpdstate &s, const double v);
4845 
4846 
4847 /*************************************************************************
4848 This function allows to set prior values used for regularization of your
4849 problem.
4850 
4851 By default, regularizing term is equal to r*||P-prior_P||^2, where r is a
4852 small non-zero value, P is transition matrix, prior_P is identity matrix,
4853 ||X||^2 is a sum of squared elements of X.
4854 
4855 This function allows you to change prior values prior_P. You can also
4856 change r with MCPDSetTikhonovRegularizer() function.
4857 
4858 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4859  S - solver
4860  PP - array[N,N], matrix of prior values:
4861  1. elements must be real numbers from [0,1]
4862  2. columns must sum to 1.0.
4863  First property is checked (exception is thrown otherwise),
4864  while second one is not checked/enforced.
4865 
4866  -- ALGLIB --
4867  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4868 *************************************************************************/
4869 void mcpdsetprior(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &pp);
4870 
4871 
4872 /*************************************************************************
4873 This function is used to change prediction weights
4874 
4875 MCPD solver scales prediction errors as follows
4876  Error(P) = ||W*(y-P*x)||^2
4877 where
4878  x is a system state at time t
4879  y is a system state at time t+1
4880  P is a transition matrix
4881  W is a diagonal scaling matrix
4882 
4883 By default, weights are chosen in order to minimize relative prediction
4884 error instead of absolute one. For example, if one component of state is
4885 about 0.5 in magnitude and another one is about 0.05, then algorithm will
4886 make corresponding weights equal to 2.0 and 20.0.
4887 
4888 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4889  S - solver
4890  PW - array[N], weights:
4891  * must be non-negative values (exception will be thrown otherwise)
4892  * zero values will be replaced by automatically chosen values
4893 
4894  -- ALGLIB --
4895  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4896 *************************************************************************/
4897 void mcpdsetpredictionweights(const mcpdstate &s, const real_1d_array &pw);
4898 
4899 
4900 /*************************************************************************
4901 This function is used to start solution of the MCPD problem.
4902 
4903 After return from this function, you can use MCPDResults() to get solution
4904 and completion code.
4905 
4906  -- ALGLIB --
4907  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4908 *************************************************************************/
4909 void mcpdsolve(const mcpdstate &s);
4910 
4911 
4912 /*************************************************************************
4913 MCPD results
4914 
4915 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4916  State - algorithm state
4917 
4918 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4919  P - array[N,N], transition matrix
4920  Rep - optimization report. You should check Rep.TerminationType
4921  in order to distinguish successful termination from
4922  unsuccessful one. Speaking short, positive values denote
4923  success, negative ones are failures.
4924  More information about fields of this structure can be
4925  found in the comments on MCPDReport datatype.
4926 
4927 
4928  -- ALGLIB --
4929  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4930 *************************************************************************/
4931 void mcpdresults(const mcpdstate &s, real_2d_array &p, mcpdreport &rep);
4932 
4933 /*************************************************************************
4934 This function serializes data structure to string.
4935 
4936 Important properties of s_out:
4937 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
4938 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
4939  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
4940 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
4941  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
4942  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
4943  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
4944  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
4945  nor you should change case of letters.
4946 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
4947  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
4948  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
4949  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
4950  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
4951  and vice versa.
4952 *************************************************************************/
4953 void mlpeserialize(mlpensemble &obj, std::string &s_out);
4954 
4955 
4956 /*************************************************************************
4957 This function unserializes data structure from string.
4958 *************************************************************************/
4959 void mlpeunserialize(std::string &s_in, mlpensemble &obj);
4960

4963 Like MLPCreate0, but for ensembles.
4964 
4965  -- ALGLIB --
4966  Copyright 18.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4967 *************************************************************************/
4968 void mlpecreate0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, const ae_int_t ensemblesize, mlpensemble &ensemble);
4969

4972 Like MLPCreate1, but for ensembles.

4974  -- ALGLIB --
4975  Copyright 18.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4976 *************************************************************************/
4977 void mlpecreate1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, const ae_int_t ensemblesize, mlpensemble &ensemble);
4978 
4979 
4980 /*************************************************************************
4981 Like MLPCreate2, but for ensembles.
4982 
4983  -- ALGLIB --
4984  Copyright 18.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4985 *************************************************************************/
4986 void mlpecreate2(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid1, const ae_int_t nhid2, const ae_int_t nout, const ae_int_t ensemblesize, mlpensemble &ensemble);
4987 
4988 
4989 /*************************************************************************
4990 Like MLPCreateB0, but for ensembles.
4991 
4992  -- ALGLIB --
4993  Copyright 18.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4994 *************************************************************************/
4995 void mlpecreateb0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, const ae_int_t ensemblesize, mlpensemble &ensemble);
4996 
4997 
4998 /*************************************************************************
4999 Like MLPCreateB1, but for ensembles.
5000 
5001  -- ALGLIB --
5002  Copyright 18.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5003 *************************************************************************/
5004 void mlpecreateb1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, const ae_int_t ensemblesize, mlpensemble &ensemble);
5005

5085 void mlperandomize(const mlpensemble &ensemble);
5086 
5087

5089 Return ensemble properties (number of inputs and outputs).
5090 
5091  -- ALGLIB --
5092  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5093 *************************************************************************/
5094 void mlpeproperties(const mlpensemble &ensemble, ae_int_t &nin, ae_int_t &nout);
5095 
5096 
5097 /*************************************************************************
5098 Return normalization type (whether ensemble is SOFTMAX-normalized or not).
5099 
5100  -- ALGLIB --
5101  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5102 *************************************************************************/
5103 bool mlpeissoftmax(const mlpensemble &ensemble);
5104 
5105 
5106 /*************************************************************************
5107 Procesing
5108 
5109 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5110  Ensemble- neural networks ensemble
5111  X - input vector, array[0..NIn-1].
5112  Y - (possibly) preallocated buffer; if size of Y is less than
5113  NOut, it will be reallocated. If it is large enough, it
5114  is NOT reallocated, so we can save some time on reallocation.
5115 
5116 
5117 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5118  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
5119  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
5120 
5121  -- ALGLIB --
5122  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5123 *************************************************************************/
5124 void mlpeprocess(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
5125 
5126 
5127 /*************************************************************************
5128 'interactive' variant of MLPEProcess for languages like Python which
5129 support constructs like "Y = MLPEProcess(LM,X)" and interactive mode of the
5130 interpreter
5131 
5132 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
5133 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
5134 when you call it from command line.
5135 
5136  -- ALGLIB --
5137  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5138 *************************************************************************/
5139 void mlpeprocessi(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
5140 
5141 
5142 /*************************************************************************
5143 Relative classification error on the test set
5144 
5145 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5146  Ensemble- ensemble
5147  XY - test set
5148  NPoints - test set size
5149 
5150 RESULT:
5151  percent of incorrectly classified cases.
5152  Works both for classifier betwork and for regression networks which
5153 are used as classifiers.
5154 
5155  -- ALGLIB --
5156  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5157 *************************************************************************/
5158 double mlperelclserror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5159 
5160 
5161 /*************************************************************************
5162 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
5163 
5164 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5165  Ensemble- ensemble
5166  XY - test set
5167  NPoints - test set size
5168 
5169 RESULT:
5170  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
5171  Zero if ensemble solves regression task.
5172 
5173  -- ALGLIB --
5174  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5175 *************************************************************************/
5176 double mlpeavgce(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5177 
5178 
5179 /*************************************************************************
5180 RMS error on the test set
5181 
5182 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5183  Ensemble- ensemble
5184  XY - test set
5185  NPoints - test set size
5186 
5187 RESULT:
5188  root mean square error.
5189  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
5190 RMS error means error when estimating posterior probabilities.
5191 
5192  -- ALGLIB --
5193  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5194 *************************************************************************/
5195 double mlpermserror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5196 
5197 
5198 /*************************************************************************
5199 Average error on the test set
5200 
5201 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5202  Ensemble- ensemble
5203  XY - test set
5204  NPoints - test set size
5205 
5206 RESULT:
5207  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
5208 it means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
5209 
5210  -- ALGLIB --
5211  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5212 *************************************************************************/
5213 double mlpeavgerror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5214 
5215 
5216 /*************************************************************************
5217 Average relative error on the test set
5218 
5219 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5220  Ensemble- ensemble
5221  XY - test set
5222  NPoints - test set size
5223 
5224 RESULT:
5225  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
5226 it means average relative error when estimating posterior probabilities.
5227 
5228  -- ALGLIB --
5229  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5230 *************************************************************************/
5231 double mlpeavgrelerror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5232 
5233 /*************************************************************************
5234 Neural network training using modified Levenberg-Marquardt with exact
5235 Hessian calculation and regularization. Subroutine trains neural network
5236 with restarts from random positions. Algorithm is well suited for small
5237 and medium scale problems (hundreds of weights).
5238 
5239 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5240  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
5241  XY - training set
5242  NPoints - training set size
5243  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
5244  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
5245  function.
5246  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
5247  Restarts - number of restarts from random position, >0.
5248  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, use 2.
5249 
5250 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5251  Network - trained neural network.
5252  Info - return code:
5253  * -9, if internal matrix inverse subroutine failed
5254  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5255  outside of [0..NOut-1].
5256  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
5257  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
5258  * 2, if task has been solved.
5259  Rep - training report
5260 
5261  -- ALGLIB --
5262  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5263 *************************************************************************/
5264 void mlptrainlm(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep);
5265 
5266 
5267 /*************************************************************************
5268 Neural network training using L-BFGS algorithm with regularization.
5269 Subroutine trains neural network with restarts from random positions.
5270 Algorithm is well suited for problems of any dimensionality (memory
5271 requirements and step complexity are linear by weights number).
5272 
5273 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5274  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
5275  XY - training set
5276  NPoints - training set size
5277  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
5278  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
5279  function.
5280  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
5281  Restarts - number of restarts from random position, >0.
5282  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, use 2.
5283  WStep - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops if step size is
5284  less than WStep. Recommended value - 0.01. Zero step
5285  size means stopping after MaxIts iterations.
5286  MaxIts - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops after MaxIts
5287  iterations (NOT gradient calculations). Zero MaxIts
5288  means stopping when step is sufficiently small.
5289 
5290 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5291  Network - trained neural network.
5292  Info - return code:
5293  * -8, if both WStep=0 and MaxIts=0
5294  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5295  outside of [0..NOut-1].
5296  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
5297  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
5298  * 2, if task has been solved.
5299  Rep - training report
5300 
5301  -- ALGLIB --
5302  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
5303 *************************************************************************/
5304 void mlptrainlbfgs(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep);
5305 
5306 
5307 /*************************************************************************
5308 Neural network training using early stopping (base algorithm - L-BFGS with
5309 regularization).
5310 
5311 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5312  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
5313  TrnXY - training set
5314  TrnSize - training set size, TrnSize>0
5315  ValXY - validation set
5316  ValSize - validation set size, ValSize>0
5317  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
5318  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
5319  function.
5320  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
5321  Restarts - number of restarts, either:
5322  * strictly positive number - algorithm make specified
5323  number of restarts from random position.
5324  * -1, in which case algorithm makes exactly one run
5325  from the initial state of the network (no randomization).
5326  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, choose one
5327  one the following:
5328  * -1 (deterministic start)
5329  * +1 (one random restart)
5330  * +5 (moderate amount of random restarts)
5331 
5332 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5333  Network - trained neural network.
5334  Info - return code:
5335  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5336  outside of [0..NOut-1].
5337  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
5338  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1, ...).
5339  * 2, task has been solved, stopping criterion met -
5340  sufficiently small step size. Not expected (we
5341  use EARLY stopping) but possible and not an
5342  error.
5343  * 6, task has been solved, stopping criterion met -
5344  increasing of validation set error.
5345  Rep - training report
5346 
5347 NOTE:
5348 
5349 Algorithm stops if validation set error increases for a long enough or
5350 step size is small enought (there are task where validation set may
5351 decrease for eternity). In any case solution returned corresponds to the
5352 minimum of validation set error.
5353 
5354  -- ALGLIB --
5355  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5356 *************************************************************************/
5357 void mlptraines(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &trnxy, const ae_int_t trnsize, const real_2d_array &valxy, const ae_int_t valsize, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep);
5358 
5359 
5360 /*************************************************************************
5361 Cross-validation estimate of generalization error.
5362 
5363 Base algorithm - L-BFGS.
5364 
5365 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5366  Network - neural network with initialized geometry. Network is
5367  not changed during cross-validation - it is used only
5368  as a representative of its architecture.
5369  XY - training set.
5370  SSize - training set size
5371  Decay - weight decay, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5372  Restarts - number of restarts, >0.
5373  restarts are counted for each partition separately, so
5374  total number of restarts will be Restarts*FoldsCount.
5375  WStep - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5376  MaxIts - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5377  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation,
5378  2<=FoldsCount<=SSize.
5379  recommended value: 10.
5380 
5381 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5382  Info - return code, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5383  Rep - report, same as in MLPTrainLM/MLPTrainLBFGS
5384  CVRep - generalization error estimates
5385 
5386  -- ALGLIB --
5387  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
5388 *************************************************************************/
5389 void mlpkfoldcvlbfgs(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, const ae_int_t foldscount, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &cvrep);
5390 
5391 
5392 /*************************************************************************
5393 Cross-validation estimate of generalization error.
5394 
5395 Base algorithm - Levenberg-Marquardt.
5396 
5397 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5398  Network - neural network with initialized geometry. Network is
5399  not changed during cross-validation - it is used only
5400  as a representative of its architecture.
5401  XY - training set.
5402  SSize - training set size
5403  Decay - weight decay, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5404  Restarts - number of restarts, >0.
5405  restarts are counted for each partition separately, so
5406  total number of restarts will be Restarts*FoldsCount.
5407  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation,
5408  2<=FoldsCount<=SSize.
5409  recommended value: 10.
5410 
5411 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5412  Info - return code, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5413  Rep - report, same as in MLPTrainLM/MLPTrainLBFGS
5414  CVRep - generalization error estimates
5415 
5416  -- ALGLIB --
5417  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
5418 *************************************************************************/
5419 void mlpkfoldcvlm(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const ae_int_t foldscount, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &cvrep);
5420 
5421 
5422 /*************************************************************************
5423 This function estimates generalization error using cross-validation on the
5424 current dataset with current training settings.
5425 
5426 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
5427 
5428  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
5429  ! this function:
5430  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
5431  ! * SSE support (C++ computational core)
5432  !
5433  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3X). First improvement
5434  ! gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems. Following
5435  ! operations can be executed in parallel:
5436  ! * FoldsCount cross-validation rounds (always)
5437  ! * NRestarts training sessions performed within each of
5438  ! cross-validation rounds (if NRestarts>1)
5439  ! * gradient calculation over large dataset (if dataset is large enough)
5440  !
5441  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
5442  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
5443  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
5444  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
5445  !
5446  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
5447  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
5448  ! * use C++ computational core
5449  !
5450  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
5451  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
5452  ! but all computations will be done serially.
5453  !
5454  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
5455  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
5456 
5457 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5458  S - trainer object
5459  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
5460  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
5461  trainer object. Network is not changed during cross-
5462  validation and is not trained - it is used only as
5463  representative of its architecture. I.e., we estimate
5464  generalization properties of ARCHITECTURE, not some
5465  specific network.
5466  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
5467  * NRestarts>0 means that for each cross-validation
5468  round specified number of random restarts is
5469  performed, with best network being chosen after
5470  training.
5471  * NRestarts=0 is same as NRestarts=1
5472  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation:
5473  * 2<=FoldsCount<=size of dataset
5474  * recommended value: 10.
5475  * values larger than dataset size will be silently
5476  truncated down to dataset size
5477 
5478 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5479  Rep - structure which contains cross-validation estimates:
5480  * Rep.RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
5481  * Rep.AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
5482  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
5483  * Rep.AvgError - average error
5484  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error
5485 
5486 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
5487  or subset with only one point was given, zeros are returned as
5488  estimates.
5489 
5490 NOTE: this method performs FoldsCount cross-validation rounds, each one
5491  with NRestarts random starts. Thus, FoldsCount*NRestarts networks
5492  are trained in total.
5493 
5494 NOTE: Rep.RelCLSError/Rep.AvgCE are zero on regression problems.
5495 
5496 NOTE: on classification problems Rep.RMSError/Rep.AvgError/Rep.AvgRelError
5497  contain errors in prediction of posterior probabilities.
5498 
5499  -- ALGLIB --
5500  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5501 *************************************************************************/
5502 void mlpkfoldcv(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, const ae_int_t foldscount, mlpreport &rep);
5503 void smp_mlpkfoldcv(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, const ae_int_t foldscount, mlpreport &rep);
5504 
5505 
5506 /*************************************************************************
5507 Creation of the network trainer object for regression networks
5508 
5509 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5510  NIn - number of inputs, NIn>=1
5511  NOut - number of outputs, NOut>=1
5512 
5513 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5514  S - neural network trainer object.
5515  This structure can be used to train any regression
5516  network with NIn inputs and NOut outputs.
5517 
5518  -- ALGLIB --
5519  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5520 *************************************************************************/
5521 void mlpcreatetrainer(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, mlptrainer &s);
5522 
5523 
5524 /*************************************************************************
5525 Creation of the network trainer object for classification networks
5526 
5527 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5528  NIn - number of inputs, NIn>=1
5529  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
5530 
5531 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5532  S - neural network trainer object.
5533  This structure can be used to train any classification
5534  network with NIn inputs and NOut outputs.
5535 
5536  -- ALGLIB --
5537  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5538 *************************************************************************/
5539 void mlpcreatetrainercls(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nclasses, mlptrainer &s);
5540 
5541 
5542 /*************************************************************************
5543 This function sets "current dataset" of the trainer object to one passed
5544 by user.
5545 
5546 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5547  S - trainer object
5548  XY - training set, see below for information on the
5549  training set format. This function checks correctness
5550  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
5551  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
5552  is passed.
5553  NPoints - points count, >=0.
5554 
5555 DATASET FORMAT:
5556 
5557 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
5558 networks, another one for classification networks.
5559 
5560 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
5561 format is used:
5562 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
5563 * each row corresponds to one example
5564 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
5565 
5566 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
5567 datasetformat is used:
5568 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
5569 * each row corresponds to one example
5570 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
5571  NClasses-1).
5572 
5573  -- ALGLIB --
5574  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5575 *************************************************************************/
5576 void mlpsetdataset(const mlptrainer &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5577 
5578 
5579 /*************************************************************************
5580 This function sets "current dataset" of the trainer object to one passed
5581 by user (sparse matrix is used to store dataset).
5582 
5583 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5584  S - trainer object
5585  XY - training set, see below for information on the
5586  training set format. This function checks correctness
5587  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
5588  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
5589  is passed. Any sparse storage format can be used:
5590  Hash-table, CRS...
5591  NPoints - points count, >=0
5592 
5593 DATASET FORMAT:
5594 
5595 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
5596 networks, another one for classification networks.
5597 
5598 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
5599 format is used:
5600 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
5601 * each row corresponds to one example
5602 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
5603 
5604 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
5605 datasetformat is used:
5606 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
5607 * each row corresponds to one example
5608 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
5609  NClasses-1).
5610 
5611  -- ALGLIB --
5612  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5613 *************************************************************************/
5614 void mlpsetsparsedataset(const mlptrainer &s, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints);
5615 
5616 
5617 /*************************************************************************
5618 This function sets weight decay coefficient which is used for training.
5619 
5620 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5621  S - trainer object
5622  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0. Weight decay term
5623  'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error function. If
5624  you don't know what Decay to choose, use 1.0E-3.
5625  Weight decay can be set to zero, in this case network
5626  is trained without weight decay.
5627 
5628 NOTE: by default network uses some small nonzero value for weight decay.
5629 
5630  -- ALGLIB --
5631  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5632 *************************************************************************/
5633 void mlpsetdecay(const mlptrainer &s, const double decay);
5634 
5635 
5636 /*************************************************************************
5637 This function sets stopping criteria for the optimizer.
5638 
5639 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5640  S - trainer object
5641  WStep - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops if step size is
5642  less than WStep. Recommended value - 0.01. Zero step
5643  size means stopping after MaxIts iterations.
5644  WStep>=0.
5645  MaxIts - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops after MaxIts
5646  epochs (full passes over entire dataset). Zero MaxIts
5647  means stopping when step is sufficiently small.
5648  MaxIts>=0.
5649 
5650 NOTE: by default, WStep=0.005 and MaxIts=0 are used. These values are also
5651  used when MLPSetCond() is called with WStep=0 and MaxIts=0.
5652 
5653 NOTE: these stopping criteria are used for all kinds of neural training -
5654  from "conventional" networks to early stopping ensembles. When used
5655  for "conventional" networks, they are used as the only stopping
5656  criteria. When combined with early stopping, they used as ADDITIONAL
5657  stopping criteria which can terminate early stopping algorithm.
5658 
5659  -- ALGLIB --
5660  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5661 *************************************************************************/
5662 void mlpsetcond(const mlptrainer &s, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits);
5663 
5664 
5665 /*************************************************************************
5666 This function sets training algorithm: batch training using L-BFGS will be
5667 used.
5668 
5669 This algorithm:
5670 * the most robust for small-scale problems, but may be too slow for large
5671  scale ones.
5672 * perfoms full pass through the dataset before performing step
5673 * uses conditions specified by MLPSetCond() for stopping
5674 * is default one used by trainer object
5675 
5676 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5677  S - trainer object
5678 
5679  -- ALGLIB --
5680  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5681 *************************************************************************/
5682 void mlpsetalgobatch(const mlptrainer &s);
5683 
5684 
5685 /*************************************************************************
5686 This function trains neural network passed to this function, using current
5687 dataset (one which was passed to MLPSetDataset() or MLPSetSparseDataset())
5688 and current training settings. Training from NRestarts random starting
5689 positions is performed, best network is chosen.
5690 
5691 Training is performed using current training algorithm.
5692 
5693 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
5694 
5695  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
5696  ! this function:
5697  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
5698  ! * SSE support (C++ computational core)
5699  !
5700  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3X). First improvement
5701  ! gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems. Following
5702  ! operations can be executed in parallel:
5703  ! * NRestarts training sessions performed within each of
5704  ! cross-validation rounds (if NRestarts>1)
5705  ! * gradient calculation over large dataset (if dataset is large enough)
5706  !
5707  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
5708  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
5709  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
5710  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
5711  !
5712  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
5713  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
5714  ! * use C++ computational core
5715  !
5716  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
5717  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
5718  ! but all computations will be done serially.
5719  !
5720  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
5721  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
5722 
5723 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5724  S - trainer object
5725  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
5726  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
5727  trainer object.
5728  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
5729  * NRestarts>0 means that specified number of random
5730  restarts are performed, best network is chosen after
5731  training
5732  * NRestarts=0 means that current state of the network
5733  is used for training.
5734 
5735 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5736  Network - trained network
5737 
5738 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
5739  network is filled by zero values. Same behavior for functions
5740  MLPStartTraining and MLPContinueTraining.
5741 
5742 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
5743 
5744  -- ALGLIB --
5745  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5746 *************************************************************************/
5747 void mlptrainnetwork(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep);
5748 void smp_mlptrainnetwork(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep);
5749 
5750 
5751 /*************************************************************************
5752 IMPORTANT: this is an "expert" version of the MLPTrain() function. We do
5753  not recommend you to use it unless you are pretty sure that you
5754  need ability to monitor training progress.
5755 
5756 This function performs step-by-step training of the neural network. Here
5757 "step-by-step" means that training starts with MLPStartTraining() call,
5758 and then user subsequently calls MLPContinueTraining() to perform one more
5759 iteration of the training.
5760 
5761 After call to this function trainer object remembers network and is ready
5762 to train it. However, no training is performed until first call to
5763 MLPContinueTraining() function. Subsequent calls to MLPContinueTraining()
5764 will advance training progress one iteration further.
5765 
5766 EXAMPLE:
5767  >
5768  > ...initialize network and trainer object....
5769  >
5770  > MLPStartTraining(Trainer, Network, True)
5771  > while MLPContinueTraining(Trainer, Network) do
5772  > ...visualize training progress...
5773  >
5774 
5775 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5776  S - trainer object
5777  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
5778  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
5779  trainer object.
5780  RandomStart - randomize network before training or not:
5781  * True means that network is randomized and its
5782  initial state (one which was passed to the trainer
5783  object) is lost.
5784  * False means that training is started from the
5785  current state of the network
5786 
5787 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5788  Network - neural network which is ready to training (weights are
5789  initialized, preprocessor is initialized using current
5790  training set)
5791 
5792 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
5793 
5794 NOTE: it is expected that trainer object settings are NOT changed during
5795  step-by-step training, i.e. no one changes stopping criteria or
5796  training set during training. It is possible and there is no defense
5797  against such actions, but algorithm behavior in such cases is
5798  undefined and can be unpredictable.
5799 
5800  -- ALGLIB --
5801  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5802 *************************************************************************/
5803 void mlpstarttraining(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const bool randomstart);
5804 
5805 
5806 /*************************************************************************
5807 IMPORTANT: this is an "expert" version of the MLPTrain() function. We do
5808  not recommend you to use it unless you are pretty sure that you
5809  need ability to monitor training progress.
5810 
5811 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
5812 
5813  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
5814  ! this function:
5815  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
5816  ! * SSE support (C++ computational core)
5817  !
5818  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3X). First improvement
5819  ! gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems. Following
5820  ! operations can be executed in parallel:
5821  ! * gradient calculation over large dataset (if dataset is large enough)
5822  !
5823  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
5824  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
5825  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
5826  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
5827  !
5828  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
5829  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
5830  ! * use C++ computational core
5831  !
5832  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
5833  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
5834  ! but all computations will be done serially.
5835  !
5836  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
5837  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
5838 
5839 This function performs step-by-step training of the neural network. Here
5840 "step-by-step" means that training starts with MLPStartTraining() call,
5841 and then user subsequently calls MLPContinueTraining() to perform one more
5842 iteration of the training.
5843 
5844 This function performs one more iteration of the training and returns
5845 either True (training continues) or False (training stopped). In case True
5846 was returned, Network weights are updated according to the current state
5847 of the optimization progress. In case False was returned, no additional
5848 updates is performed (previous update of the network weights moved us to
5849 the final point, and no additional updates is needed).
5850 
5851 EXAMPLE:
5852  >
5853  > [initialize network and trainer object]
5854  >
5855  > MLPStartTraining(Trainer, Network, True)
5856  > while MLPContinueTraining(Trainer, Network) do
5857  > [visualize training progress]
5858  >
5859 
5860 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5861  S - trainer object
5862  Network - neural network structure, which is used to store
5863  current state of the training process.
5864 
5865 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5866  Network - weights of the neural network are rewritten by the
5867  current approximation.
5868 
5869 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
5870 
5871 NOTE: it is expected that trainer object settings are NOT changed during
5872  step-by-step training, i.e. no one changes stopping criteria or
5873  training set during training. It is possible and there is no defense
5874  against such actions, but algorithm behavior in such cases is
5875  undefined and can be unpredictable.
5876 
5877 NOTE: It is expected that Network is the same one which was passed to
5878  MLPStartTraining() function. However, THIS function checks only
5879  following:
5880  * that number of network inputs is consistent with trainer object
5881  settings
5882  * that number of network outputs/classes is consistent with trainer
5883  object settings
5884  * that number of network weights is the same as number of weights in
5885  the network passed to MLPStartTraining() function
5886  Exception is thrown when these conditions are violated.
5887 
5888  It is also expected that you do not change state of the network on
5889  your own - the only party who has right to change network during its
5890  training is a trainer object. Any attempt to interfere with trainer
5891  may lead to unpredictable results.
5892 
5893 
5894  -- ALGLIB --
5895  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
5896 *************************************************************************/
5897 bool mlpcontinuetraining(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network);
5898 bool smp_mlpcontinuetraining(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network);
5899 
5900 
5901 /*************************************************************************
5902 Training neural networks ensemble using bootstrap aggregating (bagging).
5903 Modified Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm is used as base training method.
5904 
5905 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5906  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
5907  XY - training set
5908  NPoints - training set size
5909  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
5910  Restarts - restarts, >0.
5911 
5912 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5913  Ensemble - trained model
5914  Info - return code:
5915  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5916  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
5917  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
5918  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
5919  * 2, if task has been solved.
5920  Rep - training report.
5921  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
5922 
5923  -- ALGLIB --
5924  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5925 *************************************************************************/
5926 void mlpebagginglm(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &ooberrors);
5927 
5928 
5929 /*************************************************************************
5930 Training neural networks ensemble using bootstrap aggregating (bagging).
5931 L-BFGS algorithm is used as base training method.
5932 
5933 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5934  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
5935  XY - training set
5936  NPoints - training set size
5937  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
5938  Restarts - restarts, >0.
5939  WStep - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5940  MaxIts - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
5941 
5942 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5943  Ensemble - trained model
5944  Info - return code:
5945  * -8, if both WStep=0 and MaxIts=0
5946  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5947  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
5948  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
5949  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
5950  * 2, if task has been solved.
5951  Rep - training report.
5952  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
5953 
5954  -- ALGLIB --
5955  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5956 *************************************************************************/
5957 void mlpebagginglbfgs(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &ooberrors);
5958 
5959 
5960 /*************************************************************************
5961 Training neural networks ensemble using early stopping.
5962 
5963 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5964  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
5965  XY - training set
5966  NPoints - training set size
5967  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
5968  Restarts - restarts, >0.
5969 
5970 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5971  Ensemble - trained model
5972  Info - return code:
5973  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5974  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
5975  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
5976  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
5977  * 6, if task has been solved.
5978  Rep - training report.
5979  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
5980 
5981  -- ALGLIB --
5982  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5983 *************************************************************************/
5984 void mlpetraines(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep);
5985 
5986 
5987 /*************************************************************************
5988 This function trains neural network ensemble passed to this function using
5989 current dataset and early stopping training algorithm. Each early stopping
5990 round performs NRestarts random restarts (thus, EnsembleSize*NRestarts
5991 training rounds is performed in total).
5992 
5993 FOR USERS OF COMMERCIAL EDITION:
5994 
5995  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
5996  ! this function:
5997  ! * multicore support (C++ and C# computational cores)
5998  ! * SSE support (C++ computational core)
5999  !
6000  ! Second improvement gives constant speedup (2-3X). First improvement
6001  ! gives close-to-linear speedup on multicore systems. Following
6002  ! operations can be executed in parallel:
6003  ! * EnsembleSize training sessions performed for each of ensemble
6004  ! members (always parallelized)
6005  ! * NRestarts training sessions performed within each of training
6006  ! sessions (if NRestarts>1)
6007  ! * gradient calculation over large dataset (if dataset is large enough)
6008  !
6009  ! In order to use multicore features you have to:
6010  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB
6011  ! * call this function with "smp_" prefix, which indicates that
6012  ! multicore code will be used (for multicore support)
6013  !
6014  ! In order to use SSE features you have to:
6015  ! * use commercial version of ALGLIB on Intel processors
6016  ! * use C++ computational core
6017  !
6018  ! This note is given for users of commercial edition; if you use GPL
6019  ! edition, you still will be able to call smp-version of this function,
6020  ! but all computations will be done serially.
6021  !
6022  ! We recommend you to carefully read ALGLIB Reference Manual, section
6023  ! called 'SMP support', before using parallel version of this function.
6024 
6025 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6026  S - trainer object;
6027  Ensemble - neural network ensemble. It must have same number of
6028  inputs and outputs/classes as was specified during
6029  creation of the trainer object.
6030  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
6031  * NRestarts>0 means that specified number of random
6032  restarts are performed during each ES round;
6033  * NRestarts=0 is silently replaced by 1.
6034 
6035 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6036  Ensemble - trained ensemble;
6037  Rep - it contains all type of errors.
6038 
6039 NOTE: this training method uses BOTH early stopping and weight decay! So,
6040  you should select weight decay before starting training just as you
6041  select it before training "conventional" networks.
6042 
6043 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
6044  or single-point dataset was passed, ensemble is filled by zero
6045  values.
6046 
6047 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
6048 
6049  -- ALGLIB --
6050  Copyright 22.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
6051 *************************************************************************/
6052 void mlptrainensemblees(const mlptrainer &s, const mlpensemble &ensemble, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep);
6053 void smp_mlptrainensemblees(const mlptrainer &s, const mlpensemble &ensemble, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep);
6054 
6055 /*************************************************************************
6056 Principal components analysis
6057 
6058 Subroutine builds orthogonal basis where first axis corresponds to
6059 direction with maximum variance, second axis maximizes variance in subspace
6060 orthogonal to first axis and so on.
6061 
6062 It should be noted that, unlike LDA, PCA does not use class labels.
6063 
6064 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6065  X - dataset, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars-1].
6066  matrix contains ONLY INDEPENDENT VARIABLES.
6067  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>=0
6068  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
6069 
6070  :
6071  Info - return code:
6072  * -4, if SVD subroutine haven't converged
6073  * -1, if wrong parameters has been passed (NPoints<0,
6074  NVars<1)
6075  * 1, if task is solved
6076  S2 - array[0..NVars-1]. variance values corresponding
6077  to basis vectors.
6078  V - array[0..NVars-1,0..NVars-1]
6079  matrix, whose columns store basis vectors.
6080 
6081  -- ALGLIB --
6082  Copyright 25.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6083 *************************************************************************/
6084 void pcabuildbasis(const real_2d_array &x, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &s2, real_2d_array &v);
6085 }
6086 
6088 //
6089 // THIS SECTION CONTAINS COMPUTATIONAL CORE DECLARATIONS (FUNCTIONS)
6090 //
6092 namespace alglib_impl
6093 {

6100  ae_state *_state);

6146 void dsoptimalsplit2fast(/* Real */ ae_vector* a,
6147  /* Integer */ ae_vector* c,
6148  /* Integer */ ae_vector* tiesbuf,

6171  /* Integer */ ae_vector* c,
6172  ae_int_t n,
6173  ae_int_t nc,
6174  ae_int_t kmax,
6175  ae_int_t* info,
6176  /* Real */ ae_vector* thresholds,
6177  ae_int_t* ni,
6178  double* cve,
6179  ae_state *_state);
6180 ae_bool _cvreport_init(void* _p, ae_state *_state, ae_bool make_automatic);
6181 ae_bool _cvreport_init_copy(void* _dst, void* _src, ae_state *_state, ae_bool make_automatic);
6182 void _cvreport_clear(void* _p);
6183 void _cvreport_destroy(void* _p);
6184 void clusterizercreate(clusterizerstate* s, ae_state *_state);
6185 void clusterizersetpoints(clusterizerstate* s,
6186  /* Real */ ae_matrix* xy,
6187  ae_int_t npoints,
6188  ae_int_t nfeatures,
6189  ae_int_t disttype,
6190  ae_state *_state);
6191 void clusterizersetdistances(clusterizerstate* s,
6192  /* Real */ ae_matrix* d,
6193  ae_int_t npoints,
6194  ae_bool isupper,
